scenes.location: POLICE STATION, INTERVIEW ROOM MOMENTS LATER 3
characters: EXT. TITUS SPARROW PARK, SOUTH END

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quiet, cold winter night. An OLDER COP emerges from an INTERVIEW ROOM, walks down a long hall. Boston, MA - December, 1976 He reaches the front desk. A YOUNG COP looks to him, curious, as he lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG COP
dialogues.text: How's that going?

dialogues.speaker: OLDER COP
dialogues.text: The mother’s bawling and the uncle’s pissed off.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG COP
dialogues.text: She’s not married?

dialogues.speaker: OLDER COP
dialogues.text: Divorced with four kids. I guess Father was helping out.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG COP
dialogues.text: Helping out? The Older Cop shrugs. The front door opens and BURKE, FRE FACED, 32, walks in. He wears a dark overcoat.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER COP
dialogues.text: Hey, Mr. Burke. They’re in the back talking to the Bishop.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: And Father? The Older Cop nods in the other direction.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER COP
dialogues.text: We put him in the break room.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Any press?

dialogues.speaker: OLDER COP
dialogues.text: Some guy from the Citizen, but we sent him away. None of the big papers.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Let’s keep it that way. Burke walks toward the interview room.  11/26/14 2.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG COP
dialogues.text: (off Burke) Who’s that?

dialogues.speaker: OLDER COP
dialogues.text: Assistant DA.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG COP
dialogues.text: Gonna be hard to keep the papers away from the arraignment.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER COP
dialogues.text: What arraignment? He’s matter of fact. The young cop reacts, looks towards PRIEST (GEOGHAN) sitting in the break room. OLDER COP (0.C.) (CONT’D) You can tell Father Geoghan it won’t be much longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BISHOP, 50s, talks in hushed tones with SHEILA, 33. TWO BOYS, 7 and 9, sit coloring.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: Sheila, you know what good work the church does in the community. I give you my personal guarantee that I’m going to take Father out of the parish and this will never happen again. Burke enters, eyes Sheila nervously fingering ROSARY BEAD

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We'll just be another moment, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Of course, Father. The Bishop turns back to Sheila. Burke eyes the kids.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Now Sheila, I’m going to give you my personal card...  11/26/14 3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Cop stands outside smoking. He watches as the Bishop and Father Geoghan exit the police station and get into a TOWN CAR, a DRIVER behind the wheel. As they drive away, we HOLD ON the cop. PROCESSING. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large newsroom. REPORTERS and EDITORS gathered. Boston, MA - July, 2001 DEPUTY MANAGING EDITOR BEN BRADLEE JR., 50s, gruff, stand front with an older reporter, STEWART, 60s. And a cake.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Losing good reporters, it’s tough. And losing one of our best... well to put it as eloquently as I can, it’s a real kick in the ass. A few polite chuckles from those in the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But Robby’s known Stewart longer than most of you have been alive so I’m gonna turn it over to him. Robby? Ben looks to WALTER ‘ROBBY’ ROBINSON, 55, Boston Everyman

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Thanks, Ben. I think. And although I take issue with the reference to my seniority, I will say Stewart’s departure is especially painful for me. You see, for... what? 20 years now, Stewart’s been more than willing to part with his money at the poker table... (Laughter) And I got a kid in college. More laughter.

dialogues.speaker: STEWART
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I’m gonna keep playing.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Problem solved. Godspeed, buddy. Everyone’s laughing now. Robby connects in a warm, easy w

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now, Stewart, I find the timing of your departure a bit disconcerting. The corner office sits empty, the new editor arrives on Monday, so forgive me, buddy, but I gotta ask... what the hell do you know? The room hoots and laughs. Stewart covers his mouth. Spea no evil. More laughter takes us to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SACHA PFEIFFER, 28, wholesome, no bullshit, and MATT CARR mid 40s, mustache, family man, walk down the hall, into a stairwell and down a set of stairs, both carrying cake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They emerge on the floor below, Sacha eating her cake.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: How’s the cake?

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: It’s really good. Saving yours?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Nah, it’s for Mike. I can never eat at those things. They kind of depress me.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: I know. (taking a bite) You see the numbers from Washington?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Yeah. Very interesting.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: I think so too. They walk into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRAMPED OFFICE. Small windows. MIKE REZENDES, late 30s, good looks, so-so haircut, sits at his UNHOLY MESS of a d  11/26/14 5.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Uh huh. Uh huh. Uh huh. Dan, I talked to my guy at Justice, I know you guys have been dropping cases... (then) Look, Dan, I’m not asking if the PD's lying, I know they are. All I’m asking is who’s behind it? Matt sets the cake by Mike, sits at a desk full of FAMILY PHOTOS. Sacha checks messages at a tidy desk, full of boo

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: I get it. You don’t want to talk. (listens) I’m not mad, Dan, I’m hungry. We've been talking so long, I missed lunch. So I’m going to go eat, which gives you an hour to decide if you want to be on the right side of this or read about it in the paper like everyone else. Mike hangs up the phone, digs into the cake.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: You think Cahill’s got something?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Maybe, I just don’t think this story’s for us.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Ben likes it.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s not bad, it’s just not Spotlight. Robby enters.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: What’s just not Spotlight?

dialogues.speaker: SACHA MIKE
dialogues.text: The PD numbers. The numbers story. It feels thin.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh. You got Cahill to talk?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (busted) No. But I will.  11/26/14 6.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Good. Then we’ll know if it’s thin. Robby goes into his office, bit of an edge to him.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: How'd it go upstairs?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Okay. Robby gave a good speech.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: I heard Lubin and Connor are going to the Times.

dialogues.speaker: MATTY MIKE
dialogues.text: Come on, really? Yeah, I heard the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: They're leeching us.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: At least they’re sending us a guy from Miami to run things. That should help.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Has Baron even spent time in Boston?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I don’t think he’s ever been here before. Maybe we should buy him a map.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: I have a friend down at the Herald, said Baron cut 15% of the staff.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Great. Mike rolls his chair back, calls out to Robby in his offi

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Hey Robby, the new boss coming in to make cuts?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: I have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Aren’t you sitting down with him? Robby looks up, fucking Rezendes, always snooping.  10 11/26/14 7.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Yes, I am.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You think it’s about Spotlight?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: I don’t know, Mike, but I do know Ben needs an answer on the crime numbers story.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I’m telling you, I really don’t think that story’s for us.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: So you did get Cahill to talk then? Mike, annoyed, wheels back to his desk, picks up his phon

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty sits at a table reading “The Curse of the Bambino,” NOTEPAD beside him.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Mr. Baron. Marty looks up and rises to greet Robby.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Walter Robinson. Robby.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Thanks for taking time out of your weekend, Robby.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: My pleasure. (they sit) What are you reading? Marty holds up a book.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: ‘The Curse of the Bambino.’

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: (sitting) That’s a great book. The Globe has season tickets at Fenway, once you settle in.  11/26/14

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Thank you. Uh, to be honest, I’m not much of a baseball fan. I’m just trying to get a feel for city. Are you originally from Boston?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: I am, born and raised. A lot of the newsroom is from here. It really feels like a local paper in that way.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: And did that change at all after the paper was sold to the Times?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: No. I don’t think that had a big impact.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Good. (then) So, you're an editor for, uh, the Spotlight team?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: I prefer to think of myself as more of a player-coach. But yes. Are you familiar with Spotlight?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: No. Not particularly.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Well, we’re a four person investigative team. We report to Ben Bradlee Jr. and we keep our work confidential.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: What are you working on now?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: We just put out a piece on this shoddy construction outfit and right now we’re trolling around for our next story.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: How long does that typically take?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Hard to say. A couple of months.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: A couple of months.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah, we don’t like to rush it. Once we settle on a project, we can spend a year or more investigating it. Marty jots down some notes. Robby sees he’s writing a lot

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is that a concern?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Not necessarily. Uh, but from what I understand readership is down, the Internet is cutting into the Classified business and, uh, I think, uh, I’m going to have to take a hard look at things.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: So you anticipate more cuts?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I would assume so, yes, but what I’m more focused on right now is finding a way to make this paper essential to its readers.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: I'd like to think it already is.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Fair enough. I just think we can do better. Off Robby --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front of the Globe. Marty gets out of a cab, shuts th door. He walks inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben strides across the newsroom. Robby falls in.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Hey. Saw the email on the PD numbers. Looks interesting.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah. There’s something there.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: How much longer you need?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Another week.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (realizing) Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: To the 10:30.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: You? Since when?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Technically, I am an editor.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Technically. Your sit-down with Baron go that well?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: I couldn't get a read on him.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: That’s a first.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: How ‘bout you?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (shrugs ) He’s a barrel of laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Editors around a horseshoe table, side seats filled. It’s QUIET, nervous eyes on Marty, who reads some notes. Ben a editor HELEN DONOVAN, 50s, to either side. Robby sits off the side, WATCHING.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Morning everyone. Let’s get started. Do you want to say something, Marty?  15 16 11/26/14 11.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Uh, sure. (to the group) Hello. As most of you know by now, my name is Marty Baron, I’m delighted to be here. If you can tell me your name as we go around, that would be helpful. Marty looks back to his notes.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN DONONVAN
dialogues.text: Okay. Peter? Ben nods to METRO EDITOR PETER CANELLOS, 40s.

dialogues.speaker: CANELLOS
dialogues.text: Peter Canellos, Metro. We've got a major Big Dig closure that’s just been scheduled for early August... Marty makes notes. Off Ben and Robby, trading a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike, cuppa coffee, walks over to STEVE KURKJIAN’s desk.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Hey Steve. Crappy game last night.

dialogues.speaker: KURKJIAN
dialogues.text: They can’t hit worth a nickle. Mike looks toward the conference room of editors.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: What’s Eileen McNamara doing in the

dialogues.speaker: KURKJIAN
dialogues.text: Do you need something, Mike?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: No. Just curious.

dialogues.speaker: KURKJIAN
dialogues.text: I got work to do. Go be curious somewhere else, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The meeting is wrapping up.  Laughter. 11/26/14 12.

dialogues.speaker: SPORTS EDITOR
dialogues.text: .--and it looks like Pedro’s gonna be out until September lst. Jimmy says he'll be back this year, but the doc didn’t seem so sure.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: When’s the Pats opener? Except Marty.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Is that everyone?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Yes, that’s it.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Great, thank you. Uh, did everyone read Eileen McNamara’s column this weekend? The room reacts. Huh? Editors look at EILEEN MCNAMARA, 50

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: That’s the Geoghan case?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Yes, what’s the folo on that?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: It’s a column, what kind of folo were you thinking?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Well, apparently this priest molested kids in six different parishes over the last thirty years and the attorney for the victims, Mr...

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Garabedian.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Thanks, Eileen. Mr. Garabedian says Cardinal Law found out about it fifteen years ago and did nothing.

dialogues.speaker: CANELLOS
dialogues.text: I think that attorney’s a bit of a crank. And the Church dismissed the claim.  11/26/14 13.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: He said, she said.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Whether Mr. Garabedian is a crank or not, he says he has documents that prove the Cardinal knew.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: As I understand it, those documents are under seal. Silence. No one knows what to do. Robby watches.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Okay, but the fact remains, we have a Boston priest abused 80 kids, we've got a lawyer who says he has proof Law knew about it, and we've written all of... (checking his notes) ...two stories on this in the last six months? (then) This strikes me as an essential story for a local paper. At the very least, we should be going after those documents.

dialogues.speaker: CANELLOS
dialogues.text: How would you like to do that?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Well, I don’t know what the laws are here, but in Florida we would go to court. Robby raises an eyebrow. In fact, the whole room does.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: You want to sue the church?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Technically we wouldn't sue the Church. We would file a motion to lift the seal on those documents.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: The church will read that as us suing them. So will everybody else.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Good to know.  11/26/14 14. Off Robby, intrigued -- 17 INT. GLOBE, BEN’S OFFICE - LATER 17 Ben and Robby walk into Ben’s office.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Gutsy call for the first day.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: That’s one word for it.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: How do you think it’s gonna play down front?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I think Gilman’s gonna shit a brick. Knock. Knock. Mike’s at the door.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Door. Mike shuts the door, looks at Robby.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: How'd it go?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Baron wants to sue for the sealed docs in the Geoghan case.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: He wants to sue the church? That’s great.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: We covered Geoghan when the story broke three years ago. Baron was still in Miami.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: (needling Ben) I think he was at the Times then.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: He wasn’t here.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You think the suit has a chance?  11/26/14 15.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Depends on the judge.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: And what parish he belongs to. Ben’s phone RINGS. Ben picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bradlee. Yeah. Okay. (hanging up, to Robby) Baron wants to talk to us.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Us? Off Robby, surprised -- 18 INT. GLOBE, MARTY’S OFFICE - MOMENTS LATER 18

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and Robby enter. Marty’s on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Okay, thank you. Yes. Okay, thanks. Marty hangs up as they sit.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I set up a meeting for tomorrow with outside counsel...

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Jon Albano?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Who’s the Judge on this case?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Uh, Constance Sweeney.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Tough.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Why’s that?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Good Catholic girl. Marty pushes on.  11/26/14 16.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Judging from what I’ve read, it doesn’t seem like we’ve done a thorough investigation of the Geoghan case. Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: No it’s not. We looked hard at Geoghan. David Armstrong for Metro and Michael Paulson for Religion. Marty isn’t impressed.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Okay, but, uh, just so I understand, beyond our daily coverage, we haven't committed any long term investigative resources to the question of whether or not Cardinal Law knew about this?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: No, we haven’t.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (to Robby) And that’s the kind of thing your team does?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Spotlight? Well, yeah, but we’re still prospecting the Boston PD story I told you about.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Could you set it aside?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: We could.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Marty, in the past, Spotlight has had success in large part because they pick their own projects.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Would you consider picking this one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike, Sacha, Matt all working. Sacha on the phone.  11/26/14 17.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: I don’t know if he’s writing about you but I will let him know you called. Okay. Bye. Sacha hangs up as Robby enters.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Hey, how’d it go?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Okay. Baron wants us to scrub the Geoghan case.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: That’s great. MATTY Didn't we cover Geoghan?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There's a lawyer alleging Cardinal Law knew about it.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Mitch Garabedian, right? I covered him at the courthouse.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Can you get to him?

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: I only interviewed him once. He’s kind of a character.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I like characters. I'’11 take him.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: He’s yours. Also, we should talk to the lawyer who repped the victims in the Porter case. Eric MacLeish.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: That guy was always on TV.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: The Porter case? Remind me?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Father Porter, similar story, molested dozens of kids in Fall River about ten years ago.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: So we’re dropping the Boston PD?  20 21 11/26/14 18.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I vote yes.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: No, we're just setting it aside for now. I don’t need to tell you guys, we need to be more discreet than usual. Everybody’s gonna be interested in this, not just the Herald. I don’t want the Chancery getting wind of this before we know what we have.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Good luck with that. They reach for phones and computers, Robby leaves them to EXT. SACHA’S GRANDMOTHER’S HOUSE, SOUTHIE - NIGHT 20

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The quiet street dips down, disappearing into the harbour Sacha and Hansi get out of their car, cross the street. INT. SACHA’S GRANDMOTHER’S HOUSE, DINING ROOM - NIGHT 21

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cozy dining room. Sacha, her GRANDMOTHER and her husban HANSI finish dinner. Sacha’s grandmother wears a gold cro

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: When are you leaving, Nana?

dialogues.speaker: NANA
dialogues.text: The bus is picking us up in the church parking lot at nine o’clock. We have forty people going.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Is Father Dominic going?

dialogues.speaker: NANA
dialogues.text: No. He said, he’s very unlucky. But luck has nothing to do with it. Hansi can’t help but smile.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Nana won a hundred and sixty dollars last time.

dialogues.speaker: HANSI
dialogues.text: Wow.  22 23 24 11/26/14 19. INT. SACHA’S GRANDMOTHER'S HOUSE, KITCHEN - NIGHT 22 Hansi and Sacha wash dishes. They talk quietly.

dialogues.speaker: HANSI
dialogues.text: You gonna tell her?

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: We don’t even know if there’s a story yet.

dialogues.speaker: HANSI
dialogues.text: “Globe sues church?” There’s gonna be a story. Sacha continues rinsing, glances at the small, porcelain Virgin Mary on the window sill above the sink. INT. GLOBE, LARGE PUBLISHER’S FOYER - DAY 23 Marty ascends a large, open air staircase in the upscale business side of the building. He steps off, heads down t hall then stops, looks around. Lost in his own building. A YOUNG EMPLOYEE walks past.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Excuse me, do you know where the Publisher’s office is? The employee points. Marty heads that direction. INT. GLOBE, PUBLISHER’S OFFICE - DAY 24 RICHARD GILMAN, 50s, Brooks Brothers suit, finishes a cal Marty is sitting on a couch in large, plush office opposi

dialogues.speaker: GILMAN, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Thanks, Tom. Will do. (hangs up, to Marty) How are you, Marty? Settling in?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Yes, I think so.

dialogues.speaker: GILMAN
dialogues.text: Good. What can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I'd like to challenge the protective order in the Geoghan case.

dialogues.speaker: GILMAN
dialogues.text: You want to sue the Catholic Church?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: We're just filing a motion. But yes.

dialogues.speaker: GILMAN
dialogues.text: You think it’s that important?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Yes. I do.

dialogues.speaker: GILMAN
dialogues.text: Because, obviously, the Church will fight us very hard on this. Which won’t go unnoticed by our subscriber base. 53% of them are Catholic.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Uh, I think they'll be interested. Gilman considers for a long moment, looks unsettled.

dialogues.speaker: GILMAN
dialogues.text: Okay. Marty nods, gets up to go.

dialogues.speaker: GILMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Marty? Lake Street will probably contact you about a face to face with the Cardinal. It’s customary.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: They already have. It’s set up for next week.

dialogues.speaker: GILMAN
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t mention this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt walks down a row of cubicles, disappears down a spir staircase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt descends the staircase and arrives at the front desk

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Hey Lisa. Could you pull all the relevant clips on that for me? He hands her a sheet of paper. She looks at it. Reacts.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Yeah. This is for Spotlight?  25 26 27 28 11/26/14 21.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Just drop them off when they’re ready, thanks. Matt walks off. INT. MITCHELL GARABEDIAN’S OFFICE - DAY 25

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike steps off an elevator and into a DUMP of an office. eyes a small reception desk covered with FILE BOXES.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Hello. Hello? Mike peeks through an open door... a small office, cramme FLOOR TO CEILING with BOXES, each with GEOGHAN written on

dialogues.speaker: PARALEGAL
dialogues.text: Can I help you? Mike turns. A PARALEGAL pokes her head out of a cubicle.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Oh. Hi. I’m Mike Rezendes from the Boston Globe. I’m here to see Mitchell Garabedian.

dialogues.speaker: PARALEGAL
dialogues.text: He’s on a call. Please have a seat. Mike grabs a seat, checks his watch. He hears YELLING com from behind a closed door. Garabedian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robby and Sacha stride across an enormous, marble and sto lobby, a STARK CONTRAST to Garabedian’s digs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ERIC MACLEISH, 40s, good looks, quick with a story and a smile, walks into the posh room, finds Sacha and Robby.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: The famous Walter Robinson in my conference room. MacLeish and Robby shake hands.  11/26/14 22.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Good to see you again, Eric. Sacha Pfeiffer, Eric MacLeish.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you. Do you play golf?

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: (caught off guard) Uh, no.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: Good. Your colleague took some money off me at a charity event last year.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Lucky putt. I actually had my eyes closed. MacLeish smiles. Chummy.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: So, how can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: You're familiar with the Geoghan case?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: Sure. Eighty plaintiffs. All individual cases, Garabedian must be swimming.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: And the allegations against Cardinal Law? MacLeish considers the question.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: Look, it’s tricky. You need to understand these are shitty cases. The statute of limitations is only 3 years and most of these victims don’t come forward until long after that.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: They're kids. Shame. Guilt. And they come from tough neighborhoods, nobody wants to admit this kind of thing. So you’re screwed on the time limit and even if you argue your way around that, the charitable immunity statute caps damages at twenty grand.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Twenty grand for molesting a child?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: That’s the way the system works. The Church is tough. So your best shot is to try these cases in the press like I did on Porter. But most victims want nothing to do with being on TV. And Mitch isn’t exactly a people person.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: So if Garabedian can’t get these victims to talk to the press...

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: Then he has a long road ahead of him. My guess? He doesn’t have anything on Law.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: You think he’s bluffing?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: I think he’s grandstanding to cut a better deal.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Seems a bit reckless.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: Have you met Mitch Garabedian? INT. GARABEDIAN’S OFFICE - LATER 29 Mike, still waiting, checks his watch. He hears more YELL behind the door. Suddenly the door opens. A SHORT MAN exi Mike looks at the paralegal, points: “Is that him?” She shakes her head, walks off screen. Mike watches her go. Then, impatient, he stands, walks into --  11/26/14 24. 30 INT. GARABEDIAN’S OFFICE, CONFERENCE ROOM - CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small boardroom. MITCHELL GARABEDIAN, thin, 50s, sits a table buried in paperwork. He’s abrasive, to say the leas

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Mike Rezendes from the Boston Globe. I had an appointment with you about an hour ago.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: I can’t talk to you, I’m very busy. (calling to reception) Sharon?!

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Sharon went out for coffee, she said she'd be right back, I’m following up on an article...

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: The one in the Phoenix?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: No. In the Globe.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: Did you see the one in the Phoenix?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: No, I didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: I thought it was very good. I have a copy here somewhere. He starts to dig through the heap of papers.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: That's okay. I’1l track it down. I’m actually following up on a column that Eileen McNamara wrote for the Globe about your suit.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: Suits. There are eighty-four of them, it’s not a class action. You should get your facts straight.  11/26/14 25. True to word. Garabedian is a bit of crank.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You're right. I should. I’m just trying to get some background information on the Geoghan case...

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: You're not recording this are you?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: No, I wouldn’t do that without asking.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: (brusque ) I can’t show you the Church documents if that’s what you're after, they’re under seal.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I know that.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: Do you know they’ve tried to bring me before the Massachusetts Board of Bar Overseers three times? They’re watching me very closely.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: The Church?

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: Yes, the Church. They'd like to get me disbarred. In fact, put that away. (off Mike’s pad) Put it away! I don’t want you recording this in any way, shape or form. Not on paper, not on tape, nothing. In fact, I probably shouldn't even be speaking to you.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Look, Mr. Garabedian, I know there are things you can’t tell me. But I also know that there’s a story here. And I think it’s an important story.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: I already talked to the Phoenix.  11/26/14 26.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, and there’s a reason I didn’t see it, nobody reads the Phoenix anymore. They’re broke, they don’t have any power. The Globe does. And if we cover this story, everybody will hear about it.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: The Church thinks in centuries, Mr. Rezendes. You think your paper has the resources to take that on?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I do. But if you don’t mind me asking, do you? Mike’s question is non-threatening, but Garabedian reacts He stands, walking Mike to the door...

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: I don’t have the time to talk to you, Mr. Rezendes, I’m very busy. (calling out) Sharon! But before he can push Mike out the door, Mike turns back

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Can I at least talk to some of your clients? The victims? I’d like to do that.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: Call me tomorrow. I need to think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Button is pushed, CONTROL PANEL lights up. rotating library clip file comes to stop. few old newspaper clips are pulled. folder from the LARGE PHOTO clip file is pulled. Nexis search on a computer screen. Micro Fiche search on another screen. > Pp Pp Pp SP Pp YP PRINTER spits out the Micro Fiche article.  32 33 11/26/14 27. The PRINT OUT out is added to a STACK OF ARTICLES and dro into a file marked Porter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON the same file. Moving. REVEAL the folder is now one of many on a METAL CART that intern (WANDA) wheels down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A desk covered with old newspaper clips, Matt and Sacha r A knock... Wanda in the door. With the metal cart.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: I got more clips from the library.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Leave ‘em right there. Wanda the intern unloads them beside Matt’s desk.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: You guys doing a story on the Church?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: No. We are not doing a story on the Church. Wanda blanches, leaves. Robby pours some coffee.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Matt, you find anything on this guy Phil Saviano?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: No. Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: He’s part of a victims’ organization. Kurkjian ran a story on him just after the Porter case.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: There’s a victims’ organization?

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s called SNAP, Survivors Network of those Abused by Priests.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Crummy acronym.  11/26/14 28.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: You want me to track him down?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Bring him in. How much longer do you need to get through the clips?

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: A few days. There’s a lot and Lisa’s still sending stuff up. Most of it is on Porter.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Hey guys... I think I got another priest. Robby and Sacha turn. Matt stares down at a clip.

dialogues.speaker: MATT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Liam Barrett. Molested some kids in Philly then was moved to Boston, did the same thing then was moved again.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Really? Sounds like Geoghan.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Is that one of our clips?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Yeah. Byline’s Diego Ribadeneira, 1997. Must’ve been back when he was working religion.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Was there any folo?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Not much. One short piece. Looks like the Church settled the case. (then) Don’t you know Jim Sullivan?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah, why?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Looks like the Church brought him in to help out. Matt shows Robby the clip. Robby reads, surprised.  34

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing. From up above, a game in progress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike and Matt sit with Ben and Steve Kurkjian at the game called third strike and the crowd groans.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Jesus. Has anybody but Manny gotten the ball out of the infield? Matt, who’s been scoring the game, checks.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I don’t know why you bother with that thing.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: It distracts me from the game.

dialogues.speaker: KURKJIAN
dialogues.text: Know what else is good for that? Kurkjian holds up an empty beer cup. Matt stands.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Good idea. My round. I’11 be back. Anybody want food?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Hot dog. Matt heads off. Ben grabs some peanuts, turns to Mike.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: You guys making any progress?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Absolutely. It’s a good story.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Why? Cause you’re another lapsed Catholic pissed off at the Church?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: We've got some good stuff.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Like what?  11/26/14 30. Mike glances over at Kurkjian.

dialogues.speaker: KURKJIAN
dialogues.text: I’m just watching the game. Omerta.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: We got another priest, Liam Barrett.

dialogues.speaker: KURKJIAN
dialogues.text: We reported on him. (off Mike’s look) We did, I’m just saying.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Okay, but the guy was shuffled from parish to parish every few years, just like Geoghan and Porter. I think there’s a pattern. Ben looks at Kurkjian, who’s not impressed.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Sounds thin. What else you got?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Sacha found this guy from a victims’ organization, Phil Saviano.

dialogues.speaker: KURKJIAN
dialogues.text: From SNAP? Oh boy. We reported on him too.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I thought you were watching the game, Steve?

dialogues.speaker: KURKJIAN
dialogues.text: That guy’s pretty banged up, Mike.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: We ran a couple stories on him, the guy would not stop writing letters.

dialogues.speaker: KURKJIAN
dialogues.text: He wants a holy war.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: So he’s not worth taking to?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Where are you on Garabedian?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I'm working on it.  37 38 11/26/14 31.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Robby said MacLeish thinks he’s bluffing.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I think there’s something there, Ben.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Get me something solid or I'm taking you off it. I don’t want us chasing our tails on this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off Mike --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JIM SULLIVAN, 50s, lines up a tee shot. Smacks it. ROBBY and TWO OTHER GOLFERS watch as Jim talks to his ball...

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Stay away from that trap.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: You couldn't reach that trap ina million years, partner. One of the other golfers (PAUL) tees up his ball.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I’ve reached that trap before.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Now Paul, maybe. The group laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robby and Jim walk down the fairway. Robby checks the car

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: How we doing?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: We're good. We’re two up.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Good. (then) How’s the new editor working out?  11/26/14 32.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Well, he doesn’t like baseball. But he seems like a smart guy.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Yeah, I just read an article about him. Said he’s the first Jewish editor at the Globe.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Must have been a slow news day.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: He got a family?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: No, he’s not married.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Divorced?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: So the new editor of the Boston Globe is an unmarried man of the Jewish faith who hates baseball? Robby half smiles, shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They should have given it to Ben. He’s a Bradlee for crying out loud.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: He didn’t raise his hand fast enough. (then) By the way, I was reading about this priest, Father Barrett. Said you were involved in the case. Jim reacts, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Barrett, yeah. Bad egg. Lake Street asked for help, I pitched in.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: The victim said Cardinal Law knew about Barrett when he came from Philly.  11/26/14 33.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: You know I can’t talk about the case, Robby.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Off the record?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Off the record, I can’t talk about it. Is this related to the lawsuit? Now Robby hides his surprise. He stops.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: You heard about that?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Look, I don’t know this guy Baron or what his agenda is and frankly I don’t care, I just don’t want you taking a bullet for him. Jim heads off toward his ball. Off Robby, processing. 39 INT. BARBARA’S CAR, WOLLASTON PARKING LOT - LATER 39

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robby gets in. She pulls off.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: How’d you play?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Not too bad. Shoulda left my putter at home.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: How's Jimmy?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Good. He brought up the suit.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Really? What’d he say?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: He was thrilled about it.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: It’s not a surprise, Robby. The Church does a lot a good in this town. Robby nods, but something about that doesn’t sit right.  40 4l 42 42a 43 44 45 46 11/26/14 34. EXT. MATT CARROLL’S HOUSE, WEST ROXBURY - SUNDAY MORNING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt, in coat and tie, shepherds his family out the door into a minivan. His wife and daughter wear DRESSES, his s are in BLUE BLAZERS and KHAKIS -- clearly en route to chu

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST, (PRELAP)
dialogues.text: The other day I was on the world wide web. Anything you want to know. It’s right there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunday mass. Full house. A PRIEST mid homily. In back, FI Sacha, her husband, HANSI, and her GRANDMOTHER.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Now as a priest, I admit, this makes me a little nervous. Should I be worried about job security? Sacha watches her grandmother laugh with the congregation

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONGREGANTS milling outside a church.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: I don’t think so. You see knowledge is one thing. But faith is another. FIND Marty, sitting in a diner across the street, eating breakfast and reading. He glances at the church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike, in running gear, runs along the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike walks through the mostly empty newsroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike walks in, grabs a gym bag by his desk, pulls out a t when he spots... Robby. Sitting in his office. Working. INT. GLOBE, ROBBY’S OFFICE - MOMENTS LATER 46

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robby’s looking over some of the clips Matt pulled.  11/26/14 35.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Hey. Shouldn’t you be golfing? Robby looks up. Mike’s in the door, towel around his neck

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Golfing’s not a verb. And I couldn’t get a tee time today.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Is that what they call it? A tee time?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: They also call it a leisure activity. You should try it, Mike.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I run.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: You run to work. Mike shrugs, true. He eyes the clips on Robby’s desk.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: So what are you doing here today?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Looking at clips. On Saviano.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Ben and Steve think he’s a dead end. They gave me a bunch of crap about it at the game.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah, Ben emailed me.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: He did?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah. He said we should let it go.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: What do you wanna do?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Bring Saviano in.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: So just ignore those guys?  47 48 11/26/14 36.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: I think we have to start ignoring everybody on this one.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I’m good with that. (then) You think Baron has any idea what's coming down the Pike?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: No. I don’t think he cares either.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: That’s refreshing.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Unless he’s wrong. Mike registers this. EXT. LAKE STREET, CARDINAL’S RESIDENCE - DAY 47

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Audi A4 pulls up in a large parking lot. Marty gets ou looks up at the Cardinal’s MASSIVE LAKE STREET MANSION.

dialogues.speaker: CARDINAL LAW, (PRELAP)
dialogues.text: I’ve always been fascinated with the newspaper business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mahogany bookshelves, leather furniture. CARDINAL LAW, large, 50s, wears a collar and sits across from Marty.

dialogues.speaker: CARDINAL LAW
dialogues.text: I used to sit in on lectures with the Nieman fellows when I was at Harvard.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I, uh, read you were an editor once. Law chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: CARDINAL LAW
dialogues.text: Yes. A very long time ago. The Mississippi Register. Small, diocesan newspaper, but for a 30- year-old pastor it was a big responsibility. Too much at times.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: How so?  49

dialogues.speaker: CARDINAL LAW
dialogues.text: I was close with the Evers brothers, we took a stand on civil rights. Our readership was not pleased. They saw me as a meddling outsider.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I can imagine.

dialogues.speaker: CARDINAL LAW
dialogues.text: Tough seat to sit in, especially in a small town. I think you’1l find Boston’s a small town too, Marty, in many ways. But if I can be of any help, don’t hesitate to ask. I find that this city flourishes when its great institutions work together.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Uh, thank you. Personally I’m of the opinion that for the paper to best perform its function it needs to, uh, stand alone. Law reacts, surprised -- the rebuff almost feels unwarran

dialogues.speaker: CARDINAL LAW
dialogues.text: Of course, but my offer stands. A KNOCK on the door. CARDINAL LAW (CONT’D) Come in. A SECRETARY slips in with a WRAPPED GIFT. CARDINAL LAW (CONT’D) Oh. Thank you, Maureen. A little gift, Marty. Think of it as A Cardinal's guide to Boston. Law hands the gift to Marty. Who looks at it. Bemused. INT. MARTY’S CAR (PARKED), LAKE STREET - LATER 49

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty gets into to his car. He sits, unwraps the gift. A thick book, THE CATECHISM OF THE CATHOLIC CHURCH. Off Mar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. GLOBE, LOBBY - DAY 49k A MAN (SAVIANO) carrying a LARGE BOX walks up to receptio

dialogues.speaker: SAVIANO
dialogues.text: I’m here to see Sacha Pfeiffer?  50 11/26/14 38.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Name?

dialogues.speaker: SAVIANO
dialogues.text: Phil Saviano.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Okay, just a minute. The guard picks up the phone, calls upstairs. INT. GLOBE, ROBBY’S OFFICE - DAY 50 The entire team sits in Robby’s small sitting area facing PHIL SAVIANO. Phil is mid-40s, thin and twitchy. He’s got medium sized BOX in front if him. He rifles through some papers on his lap.

dialogues.speaker: SAVIANO
dialogues.text: So am I the first survivor you've talked to?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Yes, Phil. You are.

dialogues.speaker: SAVIANO
dialogues.text: Okay, well, first of all, let me say thank you for having me in today. I want you to know that you have the full cooperation of my organization, SNAP.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: How many members are there in your organization, Phil?

dialogues.speaker: SAVIANO
dialogues.text: We had eleven at our last chapter meeting. No ten. Karen just moved.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: There was a woman in your group?

dialogues.speaker: SAVIANO
dialogues.text: Of course there was a woman. They don't discriminate, not when it comes to abuse. And this has nothing to do with being gay. What this is, is priests using the collar to rape kids. Kids. Boys and girls. He reaches into a file, pulls a PHOTO of himself as a kid  11/26/14 SAVIANO (CONT’D) I was eleven. I was preyed upon by Father David Holley in Worcester. And I don’t mean prayed for. I mean preyed upon. Are any of you Catholic? The whole team looks at each other. Good question.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I was raised Catholic but now I go to my wife’s Presbyterian church.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: I'm lapsed but I go to church with my grandmother sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: It's safe to say we were all raised Catholic but now...

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Not so much.

dialogues.speaker: SAVIANO
dialogues.text: Okay. Well, let me tell you, when you're a poor kid from a poor family, religion counts for a lot. And when a priest pays attention to you it’s a big deal. He asks you to collect the hymnals or take out the trash, you feel special. It’s like God asking for help. And maybe it’s a little weird when he tells you a dirty joke but now you got a secret together so you go along. Then he shows you a porno mag, and you go along. And you go along, and you go along, until one day he asks you to jerk him off or give him a blow job. And so you go along with that too. Because you feel trapped. Because he has groomed you. How do you say no to God, right? This lands. SAVIANO (CONT’D) See, it’s important to understand that this is not just physical abuse, it’s spiritual abuse too. When priest does this to you, he robs you of your faith. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAVIANO (CONT’D) So you reach for the bottle or the needle or if those don’t work, you jump off a bridge. That’s why we call ourselves survivors. The team stares, gobsmacked. Phil pulls a book from the b We're not SAVIANO (CONT’D) Have you read Jason Berry's book? He wrote about the Gauthe case in Louisiana?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY SACHA
dialogues.text: familiar. That's G-U... SAVIANO (CONT’D) G-A-U-T-H-E. And talk to Richard Sipe. He worked in one of the Church’s ‘treatment’ centers, he’s an ex-priest, married a nun. (pulling out a file) Here, this is his testimony from the Kos case.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Phil, what’s a treatment center?

dialogues.speaker: SAVIANO
dialogues.text: It’s where they send priests when they get caught. This is all right here in the box, I sent it all to you guys five years ago.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: To the Globe? Who'd you send it to?

dialogues.speaker: SAVIANO
dialogues.text: I don’t wanna say who, but they said they weren't interested.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: But Phil, we did run a couple of stories on you. I saw them in the clips.

dialogues.speaker: SAVIANO
dialogues.text: Yeah but to be completely frank, it wasn’t enough! Robby and Mike trade a look as Phil takes a PACKET out of box overflowing with tattered clips, articles and data CD  11/26/14 41. SAVIANO (CONT’D) You guys gotta understand, this is big. It’s not just Boston, it’s the whole country, the whole world. And it goes right up to the Vatican.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Do you have any proof of that, Phil?

dialogues.speaker: SAVIANO
dialogues.text: No, not yet, but think about it, there are so many of them, how else could they have hidden it for so long?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: So many what?

dialogues.speaker: SAVIANO
dialogues.text: Priests! I know of thirteen right here in Boston.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: You know of thirteen priests who have molested children in Boston?

dialogues.speaker: SAVIANO
dialogues.text: Yeah. Why do you keep repeating everything I say?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: I just like to clarify things.

dialogues.speaker: SAVIANO
dialogues.text: Maybe you should have clarified it five years ago when I sent you all this stuff! It’s all right here. Phil’s sudden anger catches the room off guard. He stares the box, tries to pull himself together. SAVIANO (CONT’D) May I use your bathroom?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sure, Phil. Come on. Matt leads Phil out. A beat. Mike quickly starts shufflin through the packet.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: What do you think?  11/26/14 42.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: He’s got an agenda, that’s for sure.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE SACHA
dialogues.text: You think? He’s obviously been through a lot.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: But he’s smart and if he’s right about thirteen priests...

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Might be a big ‘if’ with this guy. (then to Sacha) Run background on him and follow up with some of the other survivors in his group.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I'll track down this ex-priest Sipe.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Okay. But stay on Garabedian, that’s more important.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Garabedian’s a pain in the ass.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: You can be a pain in the ass, Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garabedian walks down State Street. Mike falls in with hi

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Mitch, what a surprise. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: I’m fine, Mr. Rezendes. The light changes and Garabedian walks. Mike tags along.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Good. You know, I never heard back from you. I left you a couple messages.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: I’ve been very busy. I don’t have time for calls.  53 54 11/26/14 43.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Jeez, I’m sure you don’t. Listen, Mitch, lemme talk to a couple of your victims... You can sit in on the interview, if you're not happy you can kill it.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: I spoke to my clients, they don’t want to be in the press. I’m sorry. Garabedian walks into -- INT. GARABEDIAN’S BUILDING, LOBBY - CONTINUOUS 53 A shitty lobby, Mike follows Mitch in, continues --

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I get that but I don’t need to name names, Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: I don’t believe you, Mr. Rezendes. Mitch walks to the elevator, presses the button.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m sure you don’t.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: I don’t. The elevator opens. Mitch walks on. Mike follows him into INT. GARABEDIAN’S BUILDING, ELEVATOR - CONTINUOUS 54 The doors close. It’s cramped, but Mike keeps going.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Listen, Mitch, I’m not writing a profile here. I’m working on something bigger.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: Bigger, what does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I’m not supposed to tell you this, but I’m digging around for Spotlight. This registers with Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: Spotlight’s on this?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, we're looking into it. But I need some help, Mitch. You gotta let me talk to some of these victims. Please.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: (beat, then) Come back tomorrow. 9:30am.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Thank you. Doors open. Garabedian walks out. Mike smiles. Got him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sacha walks up to a small cafe in the South end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, bohemian cafe, mostly men. JOE CROWLEY, 42, heav boyish face, sits alone WATCHING the door. NERVOUS as shi The door opens. Sacha walks in, pauses, looking around...

dialogues.speaker: JOE CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Ms. Pfeiffer?

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Joe? He stands, almost knocking over his coffee. He starts to straighten the messy table, clean the crumbs all over it.

dialogues.speaker: JOE CROWLEY SACHA
dialogues.text: Shoot. Sorry. No, that’s okay, no problem.

dialogues.speaker: JOE CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Uh... please sit. Is this table okay? I had a muffin while I was waiting. Two actually. I eat when I'm nervous.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: I do that too. (then) I hope I’m not late. Phil said one.

dialogues.speaker: JOE CROWLEY
dialogues.text: No, you're fine. I got here early. About an hour.  57 11/26/14 45.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Would you mind if I took some of notes? Would that be alright? INT. GARABEDIAN’S OFFICE, CONFERENCE ROOM - DAY 57

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike and Garabedian sit with 25-year-old PATRICK MCSORLEY McSorley is good looking but ragged. Not outwardly nervou but he’s got a high-pitched voice and an ADDICT’S ITCH.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You don’t mind if I take some notes, do you?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK MCSORELY
dialogues.text: You gonna use my name?

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Not if you don’t want me to.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK MCSORLEY
dialogues.text: I just had a kid. He’s only one but I’m not sure I want him to know about this.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I get it.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: You can stop this interview any time you want, Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK MCSORLEY
dialogues.text: Okay. Go ‘head with your notes.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Where did you live when it first happened?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK MCSORLEY
dialogues.text: In the projects, over in Hyde Park.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Over by the Stop & Shop?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK MCSORLEY
dialogues.text: Yeah, you know it?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I drove a cab for years. Opens early, bad coffee, right?  11/26/14 46.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK MCSORLEY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess. McSorley isn’t having it.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: How old were you? When it happened.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK MCSORLEY
dialogues.text: I was twelve. My dad had just killed himself.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Jeez.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK MCSORLEY
dialogues.text: He was a real piece of shit. And my mom, she wasn’t so stable to begin with.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: What do mean?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK MCSORLEY
dialogues.text: I mean she was nuts. GARABEDIAN She was schizophrenic.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK MCSORLEY
dialogues.text: Same shit.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: So how did you meet Geoghan?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK MCSORLEY
dialogues.text: My sister saw him in the Dunkin’ Donuts. She tells him about my old man and he rushed right over. Patrick nervously itches at his arm as we CUT TO --

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAFE FRANCESCA, SOUTH END
dialogues.text: Joe talks very fast. He takes a big gulp of water.

dialogues.speaker: JOE CROWLEY
dialogues.text: ...and there was this nun, Sister Barbara, she ran this group for kids from troubled families.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Where was that?  11/26/14 47.

dialogues.speaker: JOE CROWLEY
dialogues.text: St. Ambrose in Dorchester. She's the one who introduced me to Father Shanley. He was a street priest, long hair, very hip. He invited me to his apartment in Back Bay.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Where in Back Bay?

dialogues.speaker: JOE CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Beacon Street. Are you from here?

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: I grew up in Ohio but my mom’s from Southie.

dialogues.speaker: JOE CROWLEY
dialogues.text: So you get it. I’d never even been to Back Bay.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: What happened on that first visit?

dialogues.speaker: JOE CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Well, he was very nice at first, very casual, very funny. And I think he could tell I was gay because he showed me this mobile he had, like over a baby’s crib? But with different words. Homosexual, bisexual, transsexual...

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Did you know you were gay at the time, Joe?

dialogues.speaker: JOE CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Yes, but that wasn’t information I was sharing with anybody. Not in Dorchester.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Right. So, what happened when he showed you the mobile?

dialogues.speaker: JOE CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Well, I was a little freaked out and I guess he could tell so he said, you know what will help is if we play strip poker. Of course I lost. And things went on from there.  11/26/14 48.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: What happened specifically?

dialogues.speaker: JOE CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Specifically, he molested me.

dialogues.speaker: SASHA
dialogues.text: Joe, I think the language here is going to be very important. We can’t sanitize this, just saying molest isn’t enough. People need to know what actually happened. Joe sits back, getting it as the waiter serves two coffee

dialogues.speaker: JOE CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Maybe we should get these to go. 59 INT. GARABEDIAN’S OFFICE, CONFERENCE ROOM - DAY 59

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike sits with McSorley and Garabedian.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK MCSORLEY
dialogues.text: Geoghan shows up and my mom, she’s thrilled. I mean this was like God showing up, you know?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Sure. So what happened then?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK MCSORLEY
dialogues.text: You really want to hear this shit?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, Patrick. I do. Patrick is struggling a bit. But he continues.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK MCSORLEY
dialogues.text: He offers to take me to get ice cream. He’s a priest, I’m a kid, so I go.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK MCSORLEY
dialogues.text: So we're driving home and he starts patting my leg and then... his hand just slides up and he grabs my dick. I just froze up, I was fucking petrified. I couldn’t move. I didn’t know what to do, I was just a little kid. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK MCSORLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (then) I never even touched my freakin’ ice cream, it just melted down my arm.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Did you see him again after that?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK MCSORLEY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: Alright, it’s good. Let’s stop there for now... McSorley stares down at his hands. Trembling. Then he itches his arm. This time, Mike notes the HEROIN TRACKS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sacha and Crowley walk through Peter’s Park. We can see t Cathedral in the distance. Crowley’s a little less nervou

dialogues.speaker: JOE CROWLEY
dialogues.text: He said it was a way to make me more comfortable with my body.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: And what happened next.

dialogues.speaker: JOE CROWLEY
dialogues.text: ..-he took off his clothes and said I’ve been depressed, maybe you can cheer me up and give me a blow job. Classy guy.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: And did you?

dialogues.speaker: JOE CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Yeah. I know what you must be thinking, why I would ever do that with some creepy guy thirty years older than me. But you have to understand, this was the first time in my life that someone told me it was okay to be gay. And he was a priest.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: So you had oral sex. Did you have intercourse as well?  61 11/26/14 50.

dialogues.speaker: JOE CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Yes. Not then, but later. It really messed me up. I’m sober now but that was the beginning of it all. It’s very confusing, you know, to be introduced to sex like that and then to be attracted to men... Joe tears up a bit. He stops, wipes his eyes. JOE CROWLEY (CONT’D) I’m sorry, I knew I was gonna SACHA do this. I’m sorry. Don't be sorry. It’s okay, Joe. It’s okay. Joe notices the kids on the church playground. JOE CROWLEY (CONT’D) And of course there’s a church right here. And a playground. Joe laughs nervously.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Joe, did you ever tell anyone?

dialogues.speaker: JOE CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Like who, a priest? INT. GARABEDIAN’S OFFICE, CONFERENCE ROOM - NIGHT 61

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dark now. Mike’s writing up some notes as McSorley p on his coat. Mike stands as McSorley heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK MCSORLEY
dialogues.text: Can I use your phone?

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, you know where it is. McSorley nods in thanks. Then turns to Mike.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK MCSORLEY
dialogues.text: You can use my name if you want.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Thanks, Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK MCSORLEY
dialogues.text: Don’t thank me, just get that asshole, will you? He exits. Mike lets out a breath. It’s a lot, even for hi

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: He’s one of the lucky ones. (off Mike’s look) He’s still alive. INT. KITCHEN, SACHA’S GRANDMOTHER’S APARTMENT - DAY 61A Sacha sits at the table looking through her notes. Her grandmother is at the stove cooking. Sacha notices something in her notes, stands and takes ou her cell. She walks out while she dials. SACHA’S GRANDMOTHER Would you like a cup of tea, Sacha?

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: I’m fine, Nana. Thanks. Sacha walks into -- INT. DINING ROOM, SACHA’S GRANDMOTHER’S APARTMENT - CONTI Sacha on her phone, looking over her notes.

dialogues.speaker: JOE CROWLEY, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: SACHA, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hi Joe, it’s Sacha Pfeiffer.

dialogues.speaker: JOE CROWLEY, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hi Sacha. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: SACHA, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: I’m good, thanks. Listen, Joe, there’s one thing that I wanted to follow up on. You talked to Phil Saviano about all this, right?

dialogues.speaker: JOE CROWLEY, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Yeah. I went to a couple SNAP meetings.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Right. And did Phil ever suggest doing anything about it?

dialogues.speaker: JOE CROWLEY, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: No. The meetings weren't really about that. I mean, a couple of them had gone to a lawyer but I didn’t think it was worth it.  11/26/14 52.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: JOE CROWLEY, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: There were so many forms to fill out, it was overwhelming. And he said he could get only get me a small settlement.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Who said that?

dialogues.speaker: JOE CROWLEY, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: The lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: So you did go to see a lawyer? Sacha takes out her pen, starts taking notes.

dialogues.speaker: JOE CROWLEY, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I didn’t end up using him, so I didn’t think it was important. I’m sorry. I’m not trying to hide anything.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: No, I know, Joe. Do you remember his name? The lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: JOE CROWLEY, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: No. But maybe Phil would know. The guy was on TV a lot during the Porter case. He was handsome.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Was it Eric MacLeish?

dialogues.speaker: JOE CROWLEY, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Yeah, that’s it. MacLeish. I thought he was very handsome. Off Sacha --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robby getting a coffee, paying. Matt enters.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Hey.  11/26/14 53. Matt heads for the Peanut M&Ms as Robby pays.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I was just in the newsroom, Judge Sweeney set a date for the hearing.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Two weeks. Canellos started a pool. Ten bucks to get in.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Anyone picking the Globe?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: He’s only taking bets on how fast Sweeney rules against us. Robby’s phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Huh. He heads into the hall --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robby picks up.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Robby.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hi, it’s me. Did you get my message?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: I did. Looks like Father Shanley could be our fourth priest.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: I think he is.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Did you follow up on MacLeish?

dialogues.speaker: SACHA, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: I just talked to Phil. He said MacLeish dealt with a number of these cases.  11/26/14 54. 62B INT. NANA’S HOUSE - LATER 62B Sacha is alone at the dining room table.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Guess he forgot to mention that.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: I’m gonna go to the courthouse tomorrow to see if I can find any cases he settled against the church.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Call me after you do. Good work. Robby hangs up. Sacha sits there, spent, the day and the story LANDING on her. Hard. 63 INT. GLOBE, BEN’S OFFICE - NIGHT 63 Ben packs up. A KNOCK. He turns, finds Robby with his bag

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: You wanted to chat?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I’m late for a dinner. Walk me out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and Robby walk. Robby sees Marty in his office, worki

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Does he ever go home?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Apparently not. I got guys who won't leave ‘til he does, he’s wearing out the goddamn newsroom. Robby smiles.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where are we on Geoghan?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Following up with more victims. I want to expand the investigation.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: We got a fourth priest. There might be as many as thirteen.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Thirteen? Who’s your source?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Phil Saviano. Ben stops.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Christ, Robby, I told Mike --

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: I know. I think Saviano might be legit, Ben.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: You wanna elaborate on that?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: No. Not yet. Just feels like this is stacking up. That’s my gut. Robby doesn’t embellish. The case is turning.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Good. Thanks. Robby walks off. Ben watches him go... then heads out -- INT. MIKE’S APARTMENT, EAST BOSTON - NIGHT 65

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike opens the fridge when his phone RINGS. He picks up.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: SIPE, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Mr. Rezendes?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Yeah. Who’s this?

dialogues.speaker: SIPE, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: It’s Richard Sipe.  11/26/14 56.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Oh, hey Richard, thanks for calling. Phil Saviano gave me your name, can I ask you a few questions?

dialogues.speaker: SIPE, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Of course. Mike reaches for his bag, pulls out his pad and a pen.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Great. So Phil said you worked at one of the church’s treatment centers in Baltimore...

dialogues.speaker: SIPE, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Yes, that’s right. The Seton Psychiatric Institute. It was run by the Daughters of Charity.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: And when was that, Richard?

dialogues.speaker: SIPE, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Well, I started my psychotherapy fellowship there in 1965 and I was there for five years, but I spent the next thirty studying abusive priests and their victims.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Really? That’s been your sole focus?

dialogues.speaker: SIPE
dialogues.text: Look, Mike, the church wants us to believe that it’s just a few bad apples, but it’s a much bigger problem than that.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: How much bigger?

dialogues.speaker: SIPE
dialogues.text: Well, based on the research, I would classify it as a recognizable psychiatric phenomenon. As Mike starts scribbling, sucked back in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eileen reads the paper, drinks a diet coke. Kurkjian sits nearby, working on a story and some eggs. Matt joins.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Hey Mac, if I needed historical data on a priest, parishes he'd been assigned to, where would I find it?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: For Geoghan? It’s all in the clips. Lisa has the source material.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Yeah, what if it was another priest? One that hadn’t been in the papers.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: You're looking at another priest?

dialogues.speaker: KURKJIAN
dialogues.text: Who’re you looking at? Kurkjian looks over. Matt tries to focus on Eileen.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Any ideas?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Come on Matt, you’re not going to tell me? Matt stares at her. Then pulls back.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I gotta get to a meeting. Thanks Mac. Matt beats a hasty retreat. Eileen and Kurkjian trade a look. Huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HAND pulls a BOOK off a reference shelf. FIND LISA TUIT handing Matt the 2001 CATHOLIC CHURCH DIRECTORY.

dialogues.speaker: LISA TUITE
dialogues.text: The Archdiocese puts out an annual directory, every priest and parish.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: This is great. Do these go back any further than ‘98?  68 69 11/26/14 58.

dialogues.speaker: LISA TUITE
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. They go back to the 80’s in the Mez. Beyond that, you gotta go to the BPL.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: In the Mez. Thanks, Lisa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robby and Mike walk down the hall. Mike debriefs him, a little manic, not unaffected by what he’s picked up.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: He said they all target the same kinda kid. Low income family, absentee father, broken home... They walk into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s early. The presses are relatively quiet.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: And guys like Geoghan go after boys not cause they prefer them, but cause they’re more ashamed, less likely to talk. These guys are predators, Robby. Sipe says he saw dozens of them at Seton in the 60's. He called it a “a phenomenon.”

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Why didn’t he go public?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: He did, but the church has made a huge effort to discredit him. Smear campaigns, public statements by prominent bishops. It’s just like Saviano said. And Garabedian.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: You getting anywhere with him?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: More victims.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: You can’t empty his pockets?  70 11/26/14 59.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I'll get him. I just need more time.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Come on, Mike, you gotta get him.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I'll get him, I'll get him. They open a door, walk into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dank basement, low fluorescents and rows of old books o cheap tin bookshelves. Robby and Mike react to the smell.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Jeez, what the hell is that smell?

dialogues.speaker: MATT, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: There’s a dead rat in the corner. Mike and Robby find Matt beside a HUGE STACK OF BOOKS.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: What do we got?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Church directories. It’s every priest in Massachusetts, what parish they're assigned to...

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: These are official? Mike and Robby grab directories, flipping through.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Yeah. I figured they could help us track down the priests Saviano mentioned, maybe find more victims.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: (reads, squinting) Can we turn on some more lights?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I couldn’t find the switch. You wanna borrow my glasses?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (off a directory) 1983, John Geoghan... St. Brendan’s in Dorchester. So we can see where any priest was in any given year.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (flips through another) Exactly. I got him here at... huh.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: 1980, the year he was pulled from JP. It says he’s on sick leave.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
