dialogues.text: Come on. It actually says that? Matt shows Mike. Robby urgently searches the directories.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Where’s 1991? Robby finds the 1991 Directory and opens it. He searches.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Barrett... Barrett... Liam Barrett.. I can’t read this. Can you look up Liam Barrett? (handing it to Mike) 1991's the year they pulled him out of Charlestown.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (reading) Barrett, Liam. Sick leave. He shows them. We see the designation. SICK LEAVE.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s an official designation.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Let’s get these upstairs. And Matt, let's check the priests Saviano gave us. They start to collect the directories. Robby’s cell RINGS ROBBY (INTO THE PHONE) (CONT’D) Robby.  11/26/14 61.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hey, I’m down at the courthouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sacha makes notes on a pad, a couple of files to one side

dialogues.speaker: SACHA, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Something’s not right here. A COURT CLERK (MARK) walks over.

dialogues.speaker: COURT CLERK, (MARK)
dialogues.text: There’s nothing on Shanley either, Sacha.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Okay, thanks. (into phone) We need to talk to MacLeish again.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Really. Why?

dialogues.speaker: SACHA, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: There’s nothing here. There aren't any records...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robby and Sacha have been waiting. Macleish enters.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: Thanks for waiting, so sorry guys, I got stuck on a call. What’s up?

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Mr. MacLeish, are you familiar with a priest named Paul Shanley? MacLeish looks at her. Surprised. He sits back.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: Yes, I’m familiar with him.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Have you settled cases against Father Shanley?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: As I’m sure you can understand, I can’t discuss that.  11/26/14 62.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: What about Father Ronald Paquin?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: I can’t discuss that either. Come on, guys.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: We understand you've settled several cases against each of them.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: Even if I’d been involved in those cases, the settlements would be confidential. I could be disbarred for acknowledging their existence. Robby’s not backing down. MacLeish shakes his head. ERIC MACLEISH (CONT’D) Look, I told you, these are tough cases. Most of these folks just want some acknowledgement of what happened. We got them a sit-down with the bishop and a little dough. It was the best they could hope for.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: It was certainly the best the priest could hope for.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: No, the Church promised to take the priests out of circulation.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: And did you follow up on that?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: (done with this) You guys need anything else?

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Yes. Why aren’t there any records? I was just down at the courthouse, why aren’t there any records of these settlements? MacLeish pauses. Hesitant, now not so sure of himself.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: We dealt directly with the Church. We'd draw up a demand letter and we'd send it to the chancery.  So that’s 11/26/14 63.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: You never filed anything in court?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: It was a private mediation. ano. Jesus. Sacha and Robby react.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: So this is just you and the archdiocese’s lawyers in a room?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: Correct.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Anyone else?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: Occasionally, the Church would bring in another defense attorney to help out.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: You have any names?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: (stonewalling him) No. No I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben sits with the gang.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: So this was all under the table?

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: There’s no paper trail at all. The victim has to sign a confidentiality agreement to get the settlement. The lawyer takes his third and the Church sweeps it under the rug.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Jeez. It’s a freakin’ racket.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: It’s more complicated than that. MacLeish has got a duty to his clients to get the best deal he can.  75 11/26/14 64.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Sure, but how many victims do you represent and profit from before you say something?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Garabedian would say none. That's why he’s taking these cases to court. Because he wants people to know about this.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: I agree. And, legal ethics aside, Ben, operating the way MacLeish has all but guarantees the abuse stays under wraps.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. (then) Did MacLeish confirm all of Saviano’s priests?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: No. He’s limited by the confidentiality agreement.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: But he’s clearly settled cases against a number of them. Phil’s put me in touch with some of the other victims, I’m pretty confident all of his priests are going to check out.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: So it’s thirteen priests?

dialogues.speaker: SACHA ROBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Looks that way.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Holy Shit. Okay. Keep going. off Ben --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a woman scanning a list of names on clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, what was it again?  11/26/14 65. REVEAL Marty standing next to her at the base of wide staircase. Several such women are checking off attendees.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Uh, Baron? B-A-R-O-N.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I don’t see you here.

dialogues.speaker: PETE CONLEY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: It’s okay, Kim, I can vouch for him. Marty turns, finds PETE CONLEY, 60s, Irish wealth and pow He extends a hand. PETE CONLEY (CONT’D) Pete Conley, I’m on the board of Catholic Charities. Welcome to Boston, Mr. Baron.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Uh, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: PETE CONLEY
dialogues.text: I appreciate you joining us. We’re very proud of the work we do here in Boston. (then) The Cardinal said you had a nice visit.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Uh, yes. We did.

dialogues.speaker: PETER CONLEY
dialogues.text: He’s an extraordinary man. I’m glad you had a chance to chat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty walks into the party, not knowing a soul. He stands alone, taking it in.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Enjoying yourself? Marty turns. Robby’s there. Slacks and a blazer.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Uh, to be honest, these events aren’t really my strong suit. (then) Are you involved with the charity?  11/26/14 66.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Not directly. Several of my friends are. We all went to BC High together. That’s the school across the street from the Globe.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: It’s hard to miss.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Hard to get away from too, apparently. Marty smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The Cardinal’s in the corner if you're so inclined. Robby nods. Indeed, there’s the Cardinal and he’s talking Pete Conley and few others.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: We've met.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Did he mention the suit?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: No, but he did give me a copy of the Catechism.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: (laughs ) Yeah, the Cardinal’s not known for his subtlety. During the Porter investigation, he literally called down the power of God on the Globe.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: How did that play out?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: A week later our editor broke his leg skiing. Marty reacts to Robby’s line.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Shrimp toast, gentlemen? Robby takes a shrimp.  11/26/14 67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a bowl of soup. HANDS reach for it... REVEAL Garabedian and Mike having dinner. Mike’s going over note

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You said there was a victim who filed a criminal complaint?

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: There were a few, but the judge sealed the case records after friends of the Church stepped in. The Church has a lot of friends.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Like Eric MacLeish? Garabedian sees he understands. Garabedian’s impressed.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: Let’s just say, he’s not part of the solution. You follow what I’m saying?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Sure. Mike jots down some notes. Garabedian watches him.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: You work hard, Mr. Rezendes. Are you married?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: And your wife doesn’t mind you working all the time?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, she does.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: See. That’s why I never got married. I’m too busy, what I do is too important. Garabedian salts his soup.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your new editor, he’s a Jew right?  77 11/26/14 68.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Uh, that’s right.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: He comes in, suddenly everybody is interested in the Church. You know why? Because it takes an outsider. Like me. I’m Armenian. How many Armenians do you know in Boston?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Steve Kurkjian, works at the Globe.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: That’s two! You should get a prize or something. What are you, Italian?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Portuguese.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: From where?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: East Boston.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: You don’t sound like it. Mike shrugs. Garabedian shakes his head, chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This city, these people, making the rest of us feel like we don’t belong. But they’re no better than us. Look how they treat their children. (wiping his mouth) Mark my words, Mr. Rezendes, if it takes a village to raise a child, it takes a village to abuse one. Garabedian eats. Mike ponders. Oddly moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robby crosses the room, joins Jim Sullivan at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: There he is. They two men shake.  11/26/14 69.

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wanna beer?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Love one. Jim nods to the bartender.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: You here with Barbara?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: No. She hates these things.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Karen too. Smart ladies. The bartender sets down two beers. Robby hands one to Jim

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Sldinte.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I just met your new editor, seems like a decent fella.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: I think he is. (then) I had an interesting conversation with Eric MacLeish yesterday. Turns out he’s been settling abuse cases with the archdiocese for years.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: You really wanna talk about this here?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: You said you helped out on Father Barrett as a favor, that was a one- off? Jim doesn’t say anything. Robby DARKENS.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How many of these cases have you been involved with, Jim?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: You know I can’t answer that, Robby. It’s unethical.  78 11/26/14 70.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Is that all it is? Jim stares Robby down. He drinks.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: So this is the Robby Robinson I've always heard about but never met.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Listen to me, Jimmy. You want to be on the right side of this.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: You're talking about the Church, Robby. Look around. These are good people who’ve done a lot of good for this city. (then) Enjoy the party. Jim smiles, heads into the party, leaving Robby alone at bar. Robby glances over at Marty, still on the edge of th party. So this is what it feels like to be on the outside INT. GLOBE, ROBBY’S OFFICE - DAY 78 Matt, Sacha and Mike are crammed in Robby’s office, Matt downloading the team on the directories.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I’ve been through a lot of these. ‘Sick leave’ isn’t the only designation they use when they take one of these priests out of circulation. They use a slew of terms - ‘absent on leave,’ ‘unassigned,’ ‘emergency response.’

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: They got a name for everything, these guys.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Except rape. A phone rings in the Spotlight office. Mike exits to get

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: And they move parishes way more frequently than other priests. When I was a kid, a priest moved after seven or eight years. These guys, it’s two to three tops.  79 11/26/14 71.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Did they use these designations for all of Saviano’s priests?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Yeah. It’s a pretty clear pattern. As Robby considers this, Mike calls from Spotlight --

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Guys, I’ve got Sipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The team is HUDDLED around a SPEAKERPHONE.

dialogues.speaker: SIPE, (ON SPEAKERPHONE)
dialogues.text: I think if you want to understand the crisis, you need to start with the celibacy requirement. That was my first major finding: only 50% of the clergy are celibate. They share a look. 50%? Can that be true?

dialogues.speaker: SIPE, (ON SPEAKERPHONE)
dialogues.text: Now, most of them are having sex with other adults. But this creates a culture of secrecy, that tolerates and even protects pedophiles.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: So you believe the church is aware of the extent of this ‘crisis?’

dialogues.speaker: SIPE, (ON SPEAKERPHONE)
dialogues.text: Absolutely. After the first major scandal in Louisiana, Tom Doyle, the Secretary Canonist for the Papal Nuncio, coauthored a report warning pedophile priests were a billion- dollar liability. That was in 1985.

dialogues.speaker: SIPE, (ON SPEAKERPHONE)
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Who saw this document? Anyone in the Catholic hierarchy?  11/26/14 72.

dialogues.speaker: SIPE, (ON SPEAKERPHONE)
dialogues.text: Sure. Doyle tried to introduce the report at the National Conference of Catholic Bishops. In fact, Cardinal Law initially helped to fund the report, but then he backed out and they shelved it.

dialogues.speaker: REZENDEZ
dialogues.text: (to Sacha and Matt) Are you kidding me?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Richard, Robby here. We think we have thirteen priests in Boston that fit this pattern, which would be a very big story. Does that sound right to you? In terms of scale?

dialogues.speaker: SIPE, (ON SPEAKERPHONE)
dialogues.text: No. Not really. It sounds low. My estimates suggest six percent act out sexually with minors.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Six percent of what?

dialogues.speaker: SIPE, (ON SPEAKERPHONE)
dialogues.text: Six percent of all priests. Holy shit. Robby turns to the team.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: How many priests do we have in Boston?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: About fifteen hundred. One percent is fifteen... six percent is ninety.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY SACHA
dialogues.text: Ninety priests? Is that possible?

dialogues.speaker: SIPE, (ON SPEAKERPHONE)
dialogues.text: From a metric standpoint, that would be in line with my findings. The team looks at each other. FLOORED. A beat, then --

dialogues.speaker: SIPE, (ON SPEAKERPHONE)
dialogues.text: Hello?  11/26/14 73. 80 INT. GLOBE, BEN’S OFFICE - DAY 80 Ben eats lunch, Robby and Mike download him. Ben’s shocke

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Ninety fucking priests? In Boston?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: That’s what he said.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: If there were ninety of these bastards people would know.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Maybe they do.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: And no one said a thing?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Good Germans?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I don’t think that’s a comparison you want to make publicly.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: MacLeish knew and said nothing.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: That’s thirteen priests, big difference between thirteen and ninety. Where’s this guy Sipe getting his numbers?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: He’s studied this for thirty years, he’s a trained psychotherapist --

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Okay, but we need something more than a metric from some hippy ex- priest who’s shacking up with a nun.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: So we’ll track down more victims, we'll get more priests. Then we can check them against the directories.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: That’s a shitload of victims.  81 11/26/14 74.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: We'll get them.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: How long’s it gonna take? Mike shrugs. Robby considers. Then...

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Too long. Robby gets up, moves for the door. Maybe with an idea.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Meeting over?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: For now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robby walks through the newsroom. Mike catches up to him.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: What do you got?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: What if we work backwards?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: What do you mean? From what?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: The directories. We’ve been using them to confirm bad priests. What if we do it the other way around?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (getting it) Use the directories to identify bad priests?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah, exactly. We search by designation, we look for any priest on ‘sick leave’ or ‘unnassigned’ --

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Or for priests who moved around a lot...

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah.  82

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: That’s gonna take a load of time.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Not if we’re all on it.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You too?

dialogues.text: Robby shuts his door, picks up his phone and dials. It rings. A secretary picks up.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY, (OVER THE PHONE)

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hey Robby. Everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: I need you to tell me something, Jim. Could it be ninety priests?

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Could it be as high as ninety?

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Jesus, Robby.  92 11/26/14 79.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: I need to know, Jim. I wouldn’t be asking if it wasn’t important. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: You gotta stop this, Robby. Click. Robby darkens. Then sees Sacha in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: MacLeish’s assistant said he’s all booked up, he can’t see us.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: The hell he can’t. Robby exits. Sacha quickly follows. Off Mike and Matt --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric MacLeish and a colleague get off an elevator, head o MacLeish sees Robby and Sacha sitting in the lobby, waiti for him. As they stand, MacLeish turns to his colleague.

dialogues.speaker: MACLEISH
dialogues.text: You know what, I’1l catch up with you, okay? The colleague heads off.

dialogues.speaker: MACLEISH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey guys, I’m really sorry, I am, I don’t have any time to talk right now, but if you call my assistant --

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Mr. MacLeish, we have reason to believe that there have been allegations against as many as 87 priests in Boston.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: I can’t talk about that.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Does that number sound right to you?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: You gotta be... I don’t have time for this crap.  11/26/14 80. He starts to move but Robby steps in his way, angrier tha Sacha’s ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Eric, how many priests did you settle?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: You know I can’t tell you, Robby.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: You're gonna give me their names. And the names of their victims.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: Are you threatening me? A beat. Robby controls himself, turns calm. Professional.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: We've got two stories here. We've got a story about degenerate clergy and we’ve got a story about a bunch of lawyers turning child abuse into a cottage industry. Now, which story do you want us to write? Cause we’re writing one of them. MacLeish recedes. Robby’s got him.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: I already sent you a list of names.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? To whom?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: The Globe. Years ago. After the Porter case, I got plenty of calls. I had 20 priests in Boston but I couldn't go after them without press. So I sent you guys a list of names and you buried it.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: I want those names tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC MACLEISH
dialogues.text: Check your goddamn clips, Robby. Robby turns and leaves. Sacha follows. They walk a bit.  93 11/26/14 81.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: We didn’t find anything in the clips.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Big surprise. INT. MIKE’S APARTMENT, EAST BOSTON - NIGHT 93

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike boils hot dogs on the stove.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Richard, do you still go to mass?

dialogues.speaker: SIPE, (ON SPEAKERPHONE)
dialogues.text: No, I haven’t been to church for some time now. But I still consider myself a Catholic.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: How does that work?

dialogues.speaker: SIPE, (ON SPEAKERPHONE)
dialogues.text: The Church is an institution, Mike, made of men. It’s passing. My faith is in the eternal. I try to separate the two.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Sounds tricky. Mike’s shakes his pen, out of ink. He crosses to his back by the front door. He reaches in, digs around.

dialogues.speaker: SIPE, (ON SPEAKERPHONE)
dialogues.text: It is. Especially since the Church continues to go after me. It takes a toll, Mike. SIPE (CONT’D) They’1l try to silence anyone who speaks out. I’m sure they’1ll come after you and your team soon enough.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: And how do you think they’11l do that? Hello? ...Richard? Mike checks his phone. Disconnected. Huh. Suddenly, there’s a loud KNOCK on the door. Mike JUMPS.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: The Archbishop of Canterbury. Mike opens the door. Ben’s there with a PIZZA BOX.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I had dinner at Santarpio’s, had some leftovers. He hands Mike the pizza.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Ah, you're the freakin’ best. You want a beer?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Ben enters, takes in Mike’s apartment. Mike grabs two bee Jesus. How much longer you gonna be in this shithole?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Working on it.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: She's a good girl, Mike.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, she is. We’ll figure it out. I haven't had a lot of time lately. (then) I was just on the phone with Sipe actually.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Have you met this guy in person yet?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: No, but his knowledge of this is on a whole other level. Ben frowns, skeptical. Mike hands him a beer. They sit. Mike opens the pizza box, digs in.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh man, I’m starving.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: So, where are we on the ninety?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Close.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: How close?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: We're close.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Just answer the question, will you? Mike clocks this.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: We got 87 names. We’re trying to get confirmation. I think we will. (then, off Ben) Something bugging you?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Just surprising, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, it is. For everyone. EXT. MIKE’S APARTMENT BUILDING, HALLWAY - NIGHT 93A Ben walks out of Mike’s apartment, heads up the stairs wh Mike opens his door, calls after him.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Hey. Ben, I forgot to ask, Phil Saviano said he sent a bunch of info to the Globe years ago. You have any idea to who?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (irked) No. Why?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Just curious. I wanted to see if there were any other leads you guys didn’t run out?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (pissed off) Saviano was a fucking train wreck five years ago, Mike. We didn’t miss anything. This story needed Spotlight. Mike’s taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I know. Just following up.  94 11/26/14 84. Nothing more to say.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Good night. Ben walks off. Mike watches him go. INT. GLOBE, MARTY’S OFFICE - DAY 94 CLOSE ON an EMAILED LIST of Priests and victims.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: This is unbelievable.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: When did you get this?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: MacLeish emailed the list this morning. He settled cases against forty-five priests. REVEAL Marty and Ben across the table from Robby and the of the Spotlight team. Marty pages through the printout.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Where are we on Law? Anything that shows he had knowledge of this?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: We're still working Garabedian. But nothing concrete. Marty considers this. Then he turns to Robby.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I keep thinking about that conversation we had the other night. You said Law called down the power of God when we reported on Porter.
