dialogues.text: That's just Law being Law.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Okay, but I checked the clips, Porter wasn’t even in the Boston Archdiocese. He was in Fall River. So, why the extreme reaction?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: (realizing) Law had to know. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's why he had the reaction. He knew there were others.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I think that’s the bigger story. The team reacts. Robby watches.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Bigger than fifty priests?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: If it came from the top down, yes.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: But the numbers clearly indicate senior clergy were involved.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: That’s all they do, indicate.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You're telling me we run a ROBBY story about fifty pedophile (stepping in) priests in Boston -- Mike--

dialogues.speaker: MARTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We'll get into the same cat fight you got into on Porter, which made a lot of noise but changed things not one bit. We need to focus on the institution not the individual priests. Practice and policy. Show me the Church manipulated the system so that these guys wouldn’t have to face charges. Show me they put those same priests back into parishes, time and time again. Show me this was systemic, that it came from the top down. Beat. Pretty fucking clear.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Sounds like we’re going after Law?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: We're going after the system.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The team enters together, heads for their desks. Robby ta to Sacha.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Make a list of all the victims we have and start reaching out. Pull Matt in if you need help.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: (to Mike) When you are going to Springfield?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Hearing is Monday. Robby nods, heads into -- INT. GLOBE, ROBBY’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS 94C Robby settles in. Starts to check e-mails.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Robby? You got a second? Robby looks up, Matt’s in the door.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I, uh, got one of those treatment centers a block from my house. (then) We got neighbors with kids. I know our work is confidential but I feel like I should tell ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: We'll tell ‘em soon. Matt hesitates. Then nods and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a series of quick cuts, we see -- -- Sacha (and Matt) out and about in JP, Dorchester, Miss Hill, trying to find victims. They knock on some doors and get no answer, they knock on others to find that victims have moved, it’s tough to track folks down. -- Sacha (and Matt) manage to track victims down, but fac obstacles. Obstructionist family members, reticent victims...  100

dialogues.speaker: 103A
dialogues.text: 101 11/26/14 87. -- Finally, Sacha (and Matt) actually are let in. We see shot after shot of them entering houses, some new, some where they were previously denied. They’re getting the story...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sacha sits with the middle-aged-man.

dialogues.speaker: MIDDLE-AGED-MAN
dialogues.text: The Bishop came over the house. He said nothing like this had ever happened before, they asked us not to press charges.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: And what did your mother do?

dialogues.speaker: MIDDLE-AGED-MAN
dialogues.text: My mother? She put out freakin’ cookies. Sacha blinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small apartment. MARYETTA DUSSOURD, 57, wears a gold cr

dialogues.speaker: DUSSOURD
dialogues.text: There was a lot of pressure to keep quiet. She struggles. Matt across from her, prods...

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: From the Church?

dialogues.speaker: DUSSOURD
dialogues.text: Yeah, from the Church... but not just the Church. From my friends, from the other parishioners...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a spreadsheet, going up on the wall. Names of priests, dates, reports...

dialogues.speaker: SIPE, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Well, many of the priests I treated were psychosexually stunted.... REVEAL Sacha putting up the list of 15 priests on the corkboard as Matt walks over 3x5 CARDS with VICTIM'S STOR In the foreground, Mike talks on the phone to Sipe.  11/26/14 88.

dialogues.speaker: SIPE, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: +..on the emotional level of a twelve or thirteen year old.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Jeez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sacha sits with the a COP, 40s, African-American.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Sure, the chief knew, everybody knew. But nobody wants to cuff a priest.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: What about the prosecutor?

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: I shouldn’t talk about this shit.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: I think you should actually. Sacha waits, stares him down. 103a EXT. JAMAICA PLAIN - DAY 103a Sacha talks to a painter on a ladder.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Do you know a Father Hurley or a Father Gale?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I do. 103aa EXT. TWO DECKER, DORCHESTER - DAY 103aa A man yells at Matt from his porch.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: You get out of here before I MATT kick the shit out of you, Sorry to bother you. Sorry alright? to bother you....

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: You leave me alone, leave my brother alone, you hear me goddammit?  11/26/14 89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sacha walks up to a door. The knock. A kindly looking OLD MAN (RONALD PAQUIN) in a checkered shirt answers the door

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Hi, I’m looking for Ronald Paquin.

dialogues.speaker: RONALD PAQUIN
dialogues.text: Yes? Sacha blinks, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: You're... Father Paquin?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER PAQUIN
dialogues.text: Yes, that’s right.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: (rapid, tense) My name is Sacha Pfeiffer, I, I'ma reporter with the Boston Globe.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER PAQUIN
dialogues.text: Okay. Sacha, awkward, reaches for her pad.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Could I ask you a few questions?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER PAQUIN
dialogues.text: Go ahead, dear. Sacha starts recording.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: We've talked to several men who knew you when they were boys at St. John the Baptist in Haverhill? They told us you molested them? Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER PAQUIN
dialogues.text: ...Sure. I fooled around. But I never felt gratified myself. Sacha almost hides her shock.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Right, uh, but you admit that you molested boys at St. John the Baptist?  11/26/14 90.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER PAQUIN
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, but as I said, I never got any pleasure from it. That’s important to understand.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Right. Can you tell me where and how you, uh, fooled around with these boys.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER PAQUIN
dialogues.text: I want to be clear, I never raped anyone. should know.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: How would you know? There's a difference. I

dialogues.speaker: FATHER PAQUIN
dialogues.text: I was raped.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: ...I’m sorry... who raped you?

dialogues.speaker: JANE PAQUIN, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Ronny? Who’re you talking to?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER PAQUIN
dialogues.text: It’s okay, Jane.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Father Paquin, who raped you? Paquin’s sister, JANE PAQUIN, 50s, comes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: JANE PAQUIN
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: JANE PAQUIN
dialogues.text: Please get off my porch.

dialogues.speaker: JANE PAQUIN
dialogues.text: Get inside the house, Ronald.

dialogues.speaker: JANE PAQUIN
dialogues.text: Get inside, Ronnie.

dialogues.speaker: JANE PAQUIN
dialogues.text: I’m his sister, and I don’t want you coming back here.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Sacha Pfeiffer, I’m with the Globe--

dialogues.speaker: FATHER PAQUIN
dialogues.text: I can speak for myself, Jane.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: I just have a few more--

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, who are you?

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Ms. Paquin --  105 11/26/14 gl. But Jane SLAMS the door. Sacha stands there for a moment, STUNNED. Then she turns, quickly heads down the walkway, scribbling notes. She pauses as she reaches the sidewalk, finishing up. Two CHILDREN ride past on bikes. She’s VISI SHAKEN by the encounter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike watching the Globe’s lawyer, JON ALBANO, 50s, white beard and moustache, present to JUDGE CONSTANCE SWEENEY,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE SWEENEY
dialogues.text: Could you please clarify the Globe’s position for me, Mr. Albano? The courtroom’s empty, Garabedian at one desk, WILSON D. ROGERS JR., 60s, the Church’s lawyer, at another.

dialogues.speaker: ALBANO
dialogues.text: Yes, Judge Sweeney. Our argument to make these documents public rests mainly on lst amendment grounds. We also have a number of other relevant arguments. After all, your honor, this was a discretionary order...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE SWEENEY
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Albano, it was made at the Judge's discretion... Mike FIGHTS TEDIUM... until a REPORTER slides in next to

dialogues.speaker: HERALD REPORTER, (JOE QUIMBY)
dialogues.text: Hey Mike.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Hey Joe.

dialogues.speaker: HERALD REPORTER
dialogues.text: What’s a Spotlight reporter doing in Springfield? Mike doesn’t answer. HERALD REPORTER (CONT’D) Your man Albano’s sledding uphill. You really think you have a shot at winning this thing?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You want me to comment for the Herald?  106 11/26/14 92.

dialogues.speaker: QUIMBY
dialogues.text: (writing on his pad) “Globe reporter would not comment but did not seem hopeful.” Mike settles in. Gonna be a long day. INT. GLOBE, SPOTLIGHT OFFICE/ROBBY’S OFFICE - DAY 106 Sacha downloads Robby. We see a large map of Boston on a desk, neighborhoods circled, writing and Post-its noting priests and victims.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: He didn’t try to hide it at all, he had this odd rationalization for it. Like it was normal to fool around with little boys. Nearby, we see Matt adding 3x5 victim cards to the wall. the wall, 19 OF ROUGHLY 50 PRIESTS have cards. [N.B.: The priests (and victims) should be grouped by neighborhood].

dialogues.speaker: SACHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'd really like to go back. I think he’d talk to us.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: We will. Just not yet... Let’s stay focused on victims right now.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Sacha, where’d they send Father Talbot again?

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: I think it was Cheverus? MATT Yeah, that’s right.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Father Talbot? From BC High?

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Yeah. You know him?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: He was there when I was. We have a victim?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Yeah. He lives in Providence. Matt hands him the card. Robby stares down at the name.  108 109 11/26/14 93.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike is still listing.

dialogues.speaker: ALBANO
dialogues.text: There’s nothing personal in these documents, your honor, they concern how the Cardinal is handling--

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE SWEENEY
dialogues.text: Say the Archdiocese.

dialogues.speaker: ALBANO
dialogues.text: Er, excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE SWEENEY
dialogues.text: You don’t get to tag the Cardinal with everything, Mr. Albano. Say the Archdiocese. Albano looks flustered. WILSON D. ROGERS JR. Judge Sweeney, the Globe isn’t a party to this case, they just want to sell papers. If Mr. Garabedian hadn't smeared the Cardinal’s good name, we wouldn’t even be here.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: Your honor, I object to the use of the word smear.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE SWEENEY
dialogues.text: Duly noted, Mr. Garabedian. Garabedian, angry, mutters under his breath. Mike catches

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garabedian sits on the courthouse steps, eating a packed lunch out of tupperware. Simmering.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: How you doing, Mitch? Mike walks up, sits down.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (pushing him) He’s tough, that Wilson Rogers.  11/26/14 94.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: He’s smug. And he’s sloppy.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: He doesn’t seem sloppy.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: You don’t know the half of it. Trust me.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: What’s the half of it? (then) Tell me the half of it, Mitch. Garabedian looks at him, wrestling with something.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: Off the record.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Off the record.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: Three years ago, I get a call from an ex-Priest. Anthony Benzevich. He was at Blessed Sacrament back in ‘62 and he saw Geoghan taking little boys up to the Rectory bedroom. Benzevich was appalled, he told the Bishop. And the Bishop threatened to reassign him. To South America.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Jeez.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. So, fast-forward 35 years, Benzevich reads Geoghan’s been charged with molesting more than a hundred kids. Benzevich feels guilty, he calls me.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You have testimony from a priest telling his superiors about Geoghan in 62'?

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: No, I do not. Because when I call Benzevich in to give a deposition, he shows up with a lawyer.  11/26/14 95.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Wilson Rogers.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Father Benzevich has a foggy memory. Can’t remember anything. He’s useless. So I go back to work, I forget about it, whatever. Until about a year ago. I find an article about a priest who warned church officials about Geoghan.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (stunned) Benzevich went to the press.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: Local paper, Patriot Ledger, nobody saw it. But now I got Benzevich on record, so I file a motion to depose him a second time. And Wilson Rogers, that smug son of a bitch, he files a motion opposing my motion. And that’s when I have him!

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Have him how?

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: Rogers opposes my motion. So I gotta make an argument as to why I’m allowed to depose Father Benzevich a second time. But now, I’m allowed to attach exhibits. You follow what I'm saying?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: The sealed documents...

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: Yes, I can use the sealed documents I’ve gotten in discovery, Mr. Rezendes, the same documents your paper is currently suing for.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You're shitting me.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: No, I am not shitting you. So I pull out the 14 most damning docs and I attach them to my motion. And they prove everything. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: About the Church, about the bishops, about Law...

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: And it’s all public? Because your motion to oppose Rogers’ motion...

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: »»-is public. That’s correct. Now you're paying attention.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (head spinning) So I can just walk into the courthouse right now and get those documents?

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: No. You cannot. Because the documents are not there.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: But you just said they’re public.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: I know I did. But this is Boston. And the Church doesn’t want them to be found. So they are not there.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Mitch, are you telling me that the Catholic Church had legal documents removed from the courthouse? Mitch collects his things, turns to Mike. With clarity.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: Look, I’m not crazy, I’m not paranoid, I’m experienced. Check the docket, you’ll see. They control everything. Everything. Mitch exits. Mike watches him go, UNNERVED. Is Mitch righ And was that just the mother of all tips? A beat... then Mike grabs his stuff and runs towards his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike gets out of his car, runs across same street into th courthouse.  112 113 11/26/14 97.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mousy looking CLERK #2 (O’BRIAN) pushes a BINDER across help desk to... Mike. Who starts going through the file.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Docket entry #49 in the Geoghan case. (then) We're closing in ten minutes. CLOSE ON DOCKET ENTRY #49: Plaintiff’s opposition to Reverend Anthony Benzevich’s Motion for Protective Order. Dated APR 2, 2001. Anda list of 14 exhibits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike, excited, opens the file, finds the motion and a FOL EXHIBITS A - N. Mike opens it. It’s empty. HOLY SHIT. INT. ROBBY’S HOUSE, ROBBY’S HOME OFFICE - EARLY EVENING 1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robby stands, searching through bookshelves... until he f a BC HIGH YEARBOOK. He flips to the faculty page, homing on a PHOTO... FATHER JAMES TALBOT. A beat. His phone RING

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Robby.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hey, it’s me. You’re not gonna believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike is walking out of the courthouse.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Garabedian gave me a tip, some of the sealed docs are already public. They're part of a motion he filed. He said they’re the best of the bunch, we don’t have to wait for Sweeney’s ruling.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: So we can get them?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Yeah, but they’re not there! I already talked to Albano, he said all we have to do is file a motion and Sweeney will order Mitch to refile the docs.  11/26/14 98.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: And you think these documents are...

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: He said these 14 docs are all we need. They’re huge, Robby.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Okay. I’11 call Ben. Good work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty gets out of his car and walks toward the building. a beautiful September morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s pretty empty. Marty walks in, heads toward his offic but slows when SOMETHING on a TV catches his attention. H walks to the TV, joins A YOUNG REPORTER already watching.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG REPORTER
dialogues.text: They're saying it’s a prop plane but that’s not a prop plane. We glimpse the TV. The World Trade Center. On fire.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Tell Linda to get every reporter we have in here now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a TV. Cardinal Law addressing a large group of reporters, citizens in front of the Cathedral.

dialogues.speaker: CARDINAL LAW, (REAL FOOTAGE)
dialogues.text: You pray for the injured, and those who survived. You pray, too, for the nation, that our response might reflect our best ideals and God's teaching as it is found in Christianity and Islam as well. REVEAL a group watching TV in the corner of the newsroom, front and center. Robby, Matt, Sacha are off to the side.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Not bad. Who’s there?  11/26/14 99.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE EDITOR
dialogues.text: Paulson. Ben starts to move, an editor at his side.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I wanna talk to him when he’s back. (to Robby) Did Rezendes find a way to get to Florida?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: They just opened the airport in Providence, he’s on his way there now. News to Sacha and Matt. Ben heads

dialogues.speaker: CANELLOS
dialogues.text: Ben, I’m gonna need more people on Massport.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I‘ll give you three of my guys. Robby, put your team on that too.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: And Robby, everything else stops.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Understood. off.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Why’s Mike going to Florida?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Flight school. It’s where they learned to fly.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Robby, I’ve got a lot of victim interviews set up this week.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: You’re gonna have to cancel ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: That’s going to be hard.  11/26/14 100.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: This is nuts. Two days ago, I told my wife we gotta be working the biggest story on the planet.... Robby nods as we PAN to Reception. Linda and several othe taking calls.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Boston Globe. We have no RECEPTIONIST 1 knowledge of additional Boston Globe. One second threats. please.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST 2
dialogues.text: Yes, if you have a tip I’ll transfer you to the metro desk. Off the RINGING PHONES -- INT. GARABEDIAN’S OFFICE, CONFERENCE ROOM - DAY 117

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garabedian works at his desk. The phone rings, he picks u

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Mitchell Garabedian. INT. MIKE’S CAR (MOVING), I-95 - DAY 118

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike speeds frantically down I-95 towards Providence, pho to his ear. It’s ringing.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Mitch, it’s Mike, I’ve been trying to reach you...

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: I don’t have time to talk to you, Mr. Rezendes.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Did you refile those documents yet?

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: No, I just got the order, it takes time.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Okay, great. Can you to hold off on refiling them?  120 11/26/14 101.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN MIKE
dialogues.text: Hold off? I have to go to Florida, once you refile, they’re public, other newspapers will be able to get a hold of...

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Other newspapers are not my concern. I received a judicial order, I told you the Church is watching me...

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Mitch, please, I just need a few weeks.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: I can’t make any promises. Goodbye. Garabedian hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Mitch? Mitch! Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The season has changed. The leaves are all but gone. Sach emerges from the subway, crosses the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A relatively empty bar. ON TV, we see CNN coverage of the BOMBING IN AFGHANISTAN. Phil Saviano sits in a booth acro from Sacha. Phil’s on the edge.

dialogues.speaker: SAVIANO
dialogues.text: Look, I get it, no one wants to read about kids getting raped by priests. Especially now. But you asked a lot of people to relive some very painful experiences and then you disappear!

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Phil, you know why we were SAVIANO taken off the story. It's been six weeks since 9/11.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: I realize that and we’re going to get back to it.

dialogues.speaker: SAVIANO
dialogues.text: When? You’re doing the same SACHA thing you guys did last time-- ...no...  11/26/14 102.

dialogues.speaker: SAVIANO
dialogues.text: --you’re dropping us! Maybe I should tell the Herald that story!

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Okay, Phil. You can do that, it’ll undo all the work we’ve done. But I can’t stop you. Phil looks away, but quiets.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Listen to me. I am here because I care. We are not going away. We are not going away. We are going to tell this story and we're going to tell it right. We just need more time, that’s all we’re asking for.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Why bother asking? You’re gonna do what you want anyway. You always do. He gets up and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Phil. Phil... But he’s gone. Off Sacha -- 121 INT. GLOBE, MARTY’S OFFICE - EVENING 121 Marty’s working at his computer. Ben knocks.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Marty, you gotta a second?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Sure. Marty turns as Ben walks in.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Robby’s itching to get his team back on the church story. At this point, I think we're covered on 9/11.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Okay. Sounds right. Ben starts to leave when --  11/26/14 103.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ben. (then) I, uh, wanted to say thank you for taking the lead on 9/11. All the politics at Logan and Massport, I wasn’t the person to do it. You’ve done an excellent job over the last six weeks. Ben is completely caught off guard.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Oh. Well... thanks. (awkward, exiting) Good night.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crappy hotel room. ESPN on TV, a suitcase, clothes, pap everywhere. Mike takes a burrito out of the hotel microwa tries to pick it up when his phone RINGS. He grabs the ph

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: How’s South Beach?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: I’m in Boynton Beach. Remarkably different place. What’s up?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Mitch Garabedian called me today.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Why'd he call you?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Because he knew you’d yell at him. He refiled the docs.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: (yelling) What? Robby, those docs are public now, we gotta get them before anyone else does...  11/26/14 104. 123 INT. GLOBE, ROBBY’S OFFICE/SPOTLIGHT - SAME TIME 123

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robby sitting in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: I know, wrap up what you’re doing and catch the first flight you can.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: I'll book a flight, go straight to the courthouse tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Good. Call me when you get it. Robby hangs up. Sacha is in his door, putting on her coat

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Robby, I’d like to let Phil Saviano know that we are back on it.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Good idea. Go have dinner with Hansi. Might be the last time for a while.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Okay. Sacha hesitates, then grabs a clip off her desk.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Robby, after we saw MacLeish, I started going back through the clips... and I had a little time last week finally, so, uh... (she hands him the clip) I found that. It’s from ‘93. Robby looks down. We see the clip. “LAWYER FOR PORTER VICTIMS SAYS 20 OTHER PRIESTS IN AREA ARE ACCUSED.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robby’s face CHANGES. Sacha waits, expecting a response.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: That it? Robby’s abrupt tone catches Sacha by surprise.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Yeah. That’s it.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Okay. Good night. Sacha takes a beat, then leaves, a bit confused and hurt. Robby looks down at the clip. Off Robby -- INT. MATT CARROLL’S HOUSE, BEDROOM, WEST ROXBURY, MA - NI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt sits up in bed. Checks the clock. 4am. Can’t sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt walks in, takes two aspirin. He eyes a 9/11 BUMPER STICKER on the fridge. His gaze drifts down to the photo the house on Pelton Street. Matt frowns... realizing he’s back on the church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wide shot. A well dressed, good looking MAN checking hi blackberry. Robby walks in, introduces himself to the man. PRELAP --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robby and the man, KEVIN, 40s, sit at a table. We’re ina long shot. We see them talking. Kevin is friendly, amiabl

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: So, I was probably a few years after you, right?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: More than a few.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: (laughing) Well after BC High, I came down to Providence, played hockey for the Friars.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: You must’ve been pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: No, rode the bench in college. But I loved the city, never left. We just had our third kid. And I still get my Globe, for the record.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Good to know.  129 130 131 11/26/14 106. Kevin smiles. Robby nods. Takes a beat. Then dives in.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, Kevin, that’s actually why I’m here. I need ask you some questions about Father Talbot. Kevin's face tightens, his eyes intense. Robby waits.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: How'd you find out? I guess that doesn’t matter. (shakes his head) I never even told my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike, still carrying his bags from the plane, emerges fro elevator, hurries down the hall, nearly knocking people o of the way. He arrives at the Records Room and slams up against the glass just as the clerk (O’BRIAN) LOCKS the d

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Hey, hey, I need to get in there. CLERK O’BRIAN We're closed.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Come on, let me in, five minutes, come on. CLERK O’BRIAN I’m sorry, we're closed!

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Come on, five minutes! But the clerk leaves. Mike bangs the door in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator door opens and Clerk O’Brian walks out with coffee and a copy of the Globe. He approaches the door an stops. Mike sits on the floor, waiting. O’Brian eyes him. A beat then he unlocks the door. Mike follows him into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O'Brian walks in. Mike fills out a form at the ‘applicati for records’ table. He turns to the desk, hands the form Clerk O'Brian, who reads it.  132 11/26/14 107. CLERK O’BRIAN This is the Geoghan case?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Yeah. That’s right. CLERK O’BRIAN Those records are sealed.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: No, that’s a public motion, those records are public. Look, I work for the Globe. Mike shows his credentials. CLERK O’BRIAN Good for you.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Can I talk to your supervisor? CLERK O’BRIAN He’s not in today. Mike, frustrated, eyes the CROSS the clerk is wearing.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: What about a judge? You gotta have a judge who handles these issues. The clerk eyes Mike. CLERK O’BRIAN Sixth floor. INT. SUFFOLK COUNTY COURTHOUSE, JUDGE’S CHAMBERS - LATER Mike walks in. Sees a receptionist.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I'd like to see Judge Volterra please. It’s urgent.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Judge is in court until 3:30.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: There’s no other judge on duty?

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Would you like to have a seat? Her look says it all.  133 11/26/14 108.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sure. I’11l take a seat. Mike sits. Frustrated and anxious. We PRELAP --

dialogues.speaker: JACK DUNN, (PRELAP)
dialogues.text: We understand the nature of the allegations against Father Talbot. INT. BC HIGH, PRESIDENT KEMEZA’S OFFICE, DORCHESTER - DAY Robby, Sacha sit with PRESIDENT BILL KEMEZA, 50s, SPOKESM JACK DUNN, 40, and Pete Conley, the swell we met earlier.

dialogues.speaker: JACK DUNN
dialogues.text: I’m just not sure what you want from President Kemeza. Talbot taught here long before Bill took over.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Of course. We just want to know if it’s possible that the faculty, the President, the Board, that no one knew what was going on at the time.

dialogues.speaker: JACK DUNN
dialogues.text: I graduated in 1979 and I had no idea about any of this, so if you're suggesting that Father Gibbons and Father Callahan --

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Gibbons and Callahan ran this place like the navy, Jack, you really think they didn’t know?

dialogues.speaker: JACK DUNN
dialogues.text: It’s a big school, Robby, you know that. You're talking about seven alleged victims over eight years.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Seven that we know about.

dialogues.speaker: JACK DUNN PRESIDENT KAMEZA
dialogues.text: This is ridiculous. You're Jack. Jack -- reaching for a story here, we can’t possible know if...

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT KAMEZA
dialogues.text: Jack. If I had been President back then, I would have known. Conley looks at him, sharp.  11/26/14 109.

dialogues.speaker: JACK DUNN PRESIDENT KAMEZA
dialogues.text: Bill, I’m not sure that’s Why do you think they sent relevant -- Talbot up to Cheverus? You know they wanted him out of town.

dialogues.speaker: PETER CONLEY
dialogues.text: (to Robby, direct) Robby, as well-intentioned as Bill’s remarks are, I’m hoping maybe we can keep this between us until we all get on the same page.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Is that why we’re here, to get on the same page?

dialogues.speaker: PETER CONLEY
dialogues.text: No, we’re here because you’re an important alumnus, Robby, and a friend.

dialogues.speaker: JACK DUNN
dialogues.text: Exactly. We know you care about this school as much as we do. Robby contains his anger.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Did you play a sport here, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: JACK DUNN
dialogues.text: (confused) Yeah. Football. Why?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: I ran track. (then) I went to Providence yesterday, to talk to one of Talbot’s victims, he played hockey here. He’s one of the better ones, has a wife, kids, good job. Ten minutes into the conversation guy breaks down, couldn't stop crying. Said he could never figure out why Father Talbot picked him. (beat, to Jack) Father Talbot coached the hockey team. So, I guess we just got lucky, you and me. Off Sacha, watching him.  134 135 136 11/26/14 110.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robby and Sacha walk from BC High back to the Globe.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Does Jack Dunn work for the school?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: No. He’s PR for Boston College. They call him when they need help.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: And Pete Conley? Why was he there?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Good question. Pete’s a big alum. But I called Bill directly and I asked for a sit-down, I never mentioned anybody else.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: It’s like everybody already knows the story. This hits Robby. He pauses, looks back at BC High.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah, except us. And we work right there. INT. SUFFOLK COUNTY COURTHOUSE, JUDGE’S CHAMBERS - LATER Mike is still waiting. A JUDGE enters. Mike stands.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Judge Volterra?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE VOLTERRA
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Hi, I’m Mike Rezendes from the Boston Globe. I’m having some trouble accessing some public records down in the records room. I was wondering if I could have a word with you? INT. SUFFOLK COUNTY COURTHOUSE, JUDGE’S CHAMBERS - LATER JUDGE VIERI VOLTERRA stares down at Mike’s request.  137 138 11/26/14 111.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE VOLTERRA
dialogues.text: These exhibits you’re after, Mr. Rezendes, they’re very sensitive records.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: All due respect, your honor, that’s not the question here. The records are public.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE VOLTERRA
dialogues.text: Maybe so, but tell me, where is the editorial responsibility in publishing records of this nature?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Where’s the editorial responsibility in not publishing them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clerk O’Brian drops the file in front of Mike, who dives His face says it all. HOLY SHIT. A beat, then Mike grabs the files, starts to rush out. CLERK O’BRIAN You can’t take those. You need to make copies.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m going to the copy room. CLERK O’BRIAN It closed at four. Mike stops, fucked. He digs into his pocket, counts bills

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I'll give you 83 bucks to use yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike, already on his cell phone, hurries across the stree toward and catches a cab.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Hey, Cabbie! Hey, hey, hey! Mike gets in cab.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m going to the Boston Globe on Morrisey Boulevard. Don't take 93. Take Dorchester Avenue. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into phone) Robby, it’s incredible!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike’s cab moves up State Street.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Law knew about Geoghan for years, no question! There’s a letter to Law from a woman, Margaret Gallant, who lived in Jamaica Plain in the early 80’s when Geoghan was there. Listen to this... EXT. KING’S CHAPEL, TREMONT STREET, BOSTON - MOMENTS LATE Mike’s cab whisks past the old King’s Chapel.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (reading) “Our family is rooted in the Church, our desire is to protect the Holy Orders..." EXT. MONSIGNOR REYNOLD’S WAY, SOUTH END - MOMENTS LATER 1 Mike’s cab passes the Cathedral of the Holy Cross.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “,..even in the midst of our agony over the seven boys in our family...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick McSorley plays with his kid on the playground.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ..-who have been violated." Seven, Robby! Seven boys!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cab crosses over the bridge into Dorchester.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “It was suggested we keep silent. We did not question the Authority of the Church two years ago...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cab is stuck on Old Colony Road. It turns into a TRAF CIRCLE, past St. Monica’s church and onto Columbia Road.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...but since Father Geoghan is still in his parish..." She sent it to Law and Law did shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cab drives down by the water.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Here’s another one to Law, same year. Listen to this... (reading) “A word on the recent assignment of Father John Geoghan..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cab pulls up. Mike jumps out, pays the driver, hustle inside.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “,..asS an associate at Saint Julia's in Weston. Father Geoghan..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike races in through the glass doors, then hustles up th escalator...

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “,..has a history of homosexual involvement with young boys. I understand his recent departure from Saint Brendan's may be related to this problem..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole team sits around as Mike finishes reading.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: “I wonder if Father Geoghan should not be reduced to weekend work while receiving therapy. You know how grateful I am to you for your constant concern, sincerely yours in our Lord, Most Reverend John M. D'Arcy, Auxiliary Bishop of Boston. December 7, 1984."

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: An auxiliary bishop wrote that?  11/26/14 114. We see the letters, both addressed to Law. The team reels

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: It’s incredible. He broke ranks. When did Gallant write her letter?

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: And Law just ignored her.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: How do you ignore that freakin’ letter?!

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: We've got him. You can’t read those letters and think anything else. It’s proof.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah. It is. This is good work.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Should we take it up to Ben?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: No, not yet.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Why not? We got Law. This is it.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: No, this is Law covering for one priest. There’s another 90 out there.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, and we can print that story when we get it but we gotta go with this now.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: I’m not gonna rush the story, Mike.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: We don’t have a choice, if we don’t run to press, somebody else is gonna find those letters and butcher the story! Joe Quimby from the Herald was at the freakin’ courthouse!  149 11/26/14 115.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: So we'll write a holding story and we'll keep an eye on the Herald.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (losing it) Keep our eye on the Herald? They run this and they get it wrong, the Church will bury it! We gotta do this now!

dialogues.speaker: MATTY MIKE
dialogues.text: Mike -- What? Why are we hesitating! Baron told us to get Law!

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Baron told us to get the system. We need the full scope, that’s the only thing that will put an end to this.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Then let’s take it up to Ben, let him decide!

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: We'll take it to Ben when I say it’s time.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: It’s time, Robby. They knew and they let it happen! To kids! This coulda been you, it coulda been me, it could have been any one of us. We gotta nail these scumbags, show people that no one can get away with this! Not a priest or a Cardinal or a fricking Pope! Robby, Sacha, and Matt are still. Mike looks around the r out of breath, adrenaline draining. Robby is pissed.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: You finished?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I am. This is bullshit. Mike leaves, slamming the door behind him. INT. SACHA’S HOUSE, KITCHEN - NIGHT 149

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sacha and Hansi have just finished dinner. Hansi’s cleani off the table as Sacha loads the dishwasher.  150 11/26/14 116. She tries to slide the upper rack into the dishwasher. It jammed. She tries again. It won’t go. She jiggles the rac tries a third time... she SNAPS, slamming the rack hard, sending the dirty glasses crashing into each other. She looks up... Hansi is just staring at her. Whoa.

dialogues.speaker: HANSI
dialogues.text: You okay? Before she can answer, there’s a KNOCK on the door. Hansi walks over, opens the door. It’s Mike.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Hey, Hansi.

dialogues.speaker: HANSI
dialogues.text: Hard day at work, Mike? EXT. SACHA’S HOUSE, BACK PORCH - LATER 150

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sacha walks onto the porch with two beers, hands one to M

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Thanks. I dunno why I got so pissed off. I mean I think Robby’s wrong but...

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: You care about the story, Mike. We all do. Mike takes a drink.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I stopped going to church with my Nana. It was just too hard. I'd be sitting there and I would start thinking about Joe Crowley or someone else and I’d just get so angry.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Did you tell her why?

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: She goes to church three times a week, Mike. Mike considers this. Shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Really pisses me off. (then) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, I actually liked going to mass when I was a kid.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Why’d you stop?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Typical shit. (then) But the weird thing is, I think there was a part of me that figured one day, maybe I’d go back. I was holding on to that. Sacha watches him, not expecting this.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And when I read those letters, something just cracked.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: That’s a shitty feeling.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Yeah. It’s a shitty feeling. Off the two of them, a little lost...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The posh bar of one of Boston’s oldest hotels. Robby is a the bar, a glass of red wine in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: PETER CONLEY
dialogues.text: Looks like a long day.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Hey Pete.

dialogues.speaker: PETER CONLEY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry to make it longer. Brian? Peter Conley sits, nods to the barman: ‘the usual.’

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Anyone ever said no to a drink with you, Pete?

dialogues.speaker: PETER CONLEY
dialogues.text: Sure. The trick is to keep asking. (raising his glass) For Boston.  11/26/14 118.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: For Boston. (drinks, then) So, you here for the Cardinal?

dialogues.speaker: PETER CONLEY
dialogues.text: No, no, I wouldn’t presume to speak for the Cardinal. (then) You gotta a lot of people here who respect you, Robby, respect your work.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Good to know.

dialogues.speaker: PETER CONLEY
dialogues.text: It’s ‘cause you care about this place. It’s why you do what you do, it’s who you are. But people need the Church more than ever right now. You can feel it. And the Cardinal May not be perfect but we can’t throw out all the good he’s doing over a few bad apples. Robby lets this sink in. Nods as if in agreement. PETER CONLEY (CONT’D) I’m bringing this up with you because I know this is Baron’s idea. His agenda. And I gotta tell you, honest to God, I don’t think he cares about this city the way we do. How could he? Robby looks at Conley. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: This is how it happens, isn’t it, Pete?

dialogues.speaker: PETER CONLEY
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: A guy leans on a guy and suddenly the whole town just looks the other way. Stung. Pete downs his drink. Gets up.  153 154 11/26/14 119.

dialogues.speaker: PETER CONLEY
dialogues.text: Robby, look. Marty Baron is just trying to make his mark. He’1ll be here for a couple years and he’s gonna move on. Just like he did in New York and Miami. Where you gonna go? He starts to go.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Pete? (Pete turns) When we do run the story, I’m gonna need a comment from the Cardinal. Conley takes it. Then smiles.

dialogues.speaker: PETER CONLEY
dialogues.text: We'll talk again later. Good night, Robby. INT. GLOBE, ROBBY’S OFFICE/SPOTLIGHT OFFICE - DAY 153

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robby, Mike, Sacha and Matt sit working. It’s dark, quiet serious. A beat, then Robby’s phone RINGS. He answers.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Robby. What? No shit, when? Okay. (hangs up, calls out) Hey. The team looks towards Robby’s office as he walks in.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: What’s up?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Sweeney ruled in our favor. She ruled to unseal the documents.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Jeez... The group sits stunned. INT. GLOBE, MARTY’S OFFICE - EARLY EVENING 154

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty, Ben, Robby, and Canellos (the Metro editor we met earlier) sit with the Globe lawyer, Albano.  11/26/14 120.

dialogues.speaker: ALBANO
dialogues.text: The Church already filed an appeal. But the trial court’s ruling is generally upheld in these matters.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: And when would we get the documents?

dialogues.speaker: ALBANO
dialogues.text: Probably takes Cohen a few weeks to rule, then there’1l be a redaction process... I’d say they’1ll be made public mid-January.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Okay. Thanks, John. And nice work. Albano exits.

dialogues.speaker: CANELLOS
dialogues.text: Metro should run something, Marty.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: We can’t run this big.

dialogues.speaker: CANELLOS
dialogues.text: Why wouldn’t we? It’s a major First Amendment victory. Not to mention, an Irish Catholic judge rules against the church? That’s a hell of a precedent.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: (to Ben) We don’t want the Herald going too deep on this.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Why’s that?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: You’re gonna have to step out, Peter.

dialogues.speaker: CANELLOS
dialogues.text: I’m not stepping out. Robby picks up a FOLDER OF DOCUMENTS on the table beside He places it in front of Marty. Marty picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Peter. Marching orders. Canellos exits, not happy.  11/26/14 121. 155 INT. GLOBE, MARTY’S OFFICE - MOMENTS LATER 155 CLOSE ON the letters. Reveal Marty and Ben reading, STUNN

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: When did you --

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: A couple of weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: A couple of weeks?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: And you're telling us now?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: These are substantial. They clearly show that Law was negligent. Ben and Marty stare at Robby. A beat, then --

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: I need more time. I want to keep digging.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: For what? This is the goddamn story.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: It’s not the whole story.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (dismissive) Tough shit. We’re on a clock now. Even if we don’t run Sweeney's ruling, another paper could find these letters and fuck the story.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Agreed. But we run the letters alone, Law apologizes, says it’s a one time thing, he can bury it.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: How? These clearly show he knew and did nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Look, I’m close to stories on 70 priests. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We nail that along with those letters, it’s proof that this is bigger than Law. It’s the whole system. Marty considers.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: You have multiple sources confirming the 70 priests?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: On some. I can get more.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Too risky. If we’re not buttoned up on every single one of them, the Church’11 pick us apart. Robby’s up against it. He plays his hand.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: I think I can get someone from the other side of the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Someone inside the Church?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah, a lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Will he go on the record?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Deep background. But he’s a solid source. Marty considers. A beat, then Ben steps in.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Rezendes needs time to write up the story. We don’t want to drop this at Christmas, not after 9/11. We could run it just after New Year's, before the rest of the documents are released.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Okay. Tell Canellos to bury the ruling in Metro. (then, to Robby) You've got six weeks.  156 157
Robby nods, gets up and leaves. Ben follows him into -- INT. GLOBE, NEWSROOM OUTSIDE MARTY’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and Robby walk out.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Tell Mike I want a draft before Christmas. And we need a response from Lake Street. Who does PR for the Cardinal? Still John Walsh?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: No, somebody new, Donna Morrisey, she came from TV, she’s young.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Good, get a quote, we need something from Law to appear even-handed.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: And Robby? Next time give me a goddamn heads up? Ben exits. Robby takes it on the chin then walks off. As does, we hear a child’s voice start into SILENT NIGHT...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a second child joins in, we see a SERIES OF SHOTS... MIKE’S COMPUTER. 41 days until deadline. The very 157A start of the story. FIND Mike in SPOTLIGHT, pecking out the story on his COMPUTER. Matt, coat and briefcase, walks out... Sacha with Phil, Crowley and another guy at a shitty 1571 DINER, sad Christmas decor. Sacha doesn’t eat, she writes on a pad. MIKE’S COMPUTER. 21 days until deadline. The story 157Fa is further along... Matt drives down the street in HIS CAR, eyes on an old 15 man, putting down salt on the front walk of the TREATMENT CENTER. In BEN’S OFFICE, Mike watches Ben and Robby read the 157E story. Cross outs. He hands it back to Mike. Not there yet.

dialogues.speaker: 157M
dialogues.text: 161 162 11/26/14 124. A SMALL HYDE PARK LIVING ROOM. A man in 40s cries, 157F talking to Sacha. A Christmas tree in the background. MIKE’S COMPUTER. 8 days until deadline. More edits on 157 the story. FIND Mike in his APARTMENT. Editing. A beer by the computer... An E-MAIL to Robby from Ben: ‘Where are we on your 157Ja source? It's time.’ Find Robby IN HIS OFFICE, staring at the computer. A night mass at an EAST BOSTON CHURCH. 157M As the children’s choir finishes Silent Night, we FIND Mike, in the doorway, standing there. Watching. Cut to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door of a pretty colonial, a wreath still up. A hand knocks. The door opens. A pretty woman (JIM’'S WIFE) smil

dialogues.speaker: JIM'S WIFE
dialogues.text: Robby. What a nice surprise. REVEAL Robby at the door. He walks into -- INT. SULLIVAN HOUSE, JIM’S HOME OFFICE - MOMENTS LATER 16 Jim sits at on a leather couch watching golf. Through a door, we see a Christmas tree. His wife and Robby walk in

dialogues.speaker: JIM'S WIFE
dialogues.text: Look who I found outside. Jim looks up, less than happy to see Robby standing there

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Hon, give us a minute, will you? Jim's wife looks surprised.

dialogues.speaker: JIM'S WIFE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Good to see you, Karen. She leaves. Jim turns off the TV,

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: What’s up? Robby pulls out a list, hands it to Jim.  163 11/26/14 125.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: I’m out of time, Jim. We've got cover-up stories on 70 priests, but the boss isn’t gonna run it unless I get confirmation from your side. Jim turns off the TV, looks it over.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Are you out of your mind?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Come on. This is our town, Jimmy. We all knew something was going on and no one did a thing. We gotta put an end to it.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me what I gotta do! Yeah, I helped defend these scumbags, but that’s my job, Robby. I was doing my job!

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah. You and everyone else. Jim stands, hands Robby the list.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Get out of my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robby walks out of the house, toward his car.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Hey! Robby turns, finds Sullivan.

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You come to my home and lay this shit on me! (then) You're right, Robby, we all knew something was going to on. So where were you? What took you so long?! This lands with Robby. No answer.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: I don’t know, Jimmy. Jim shakes his head, looks like he might slug Robby.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Give me the list. Jim holds out his hand. Robby hands him the list. Jim eye the first page, flips to the second. He checks the names. then flips back. He looks at Robby. Holds out a hand for pen. Robby gives him one. Jim leans on the roof of Robby’s car. Marks up the list, then hands it back to Robby. Nothing more to say, Jim tur and walks away. Robby looks down at the list. Reacts. THE ENTIRE first page is CIRCLED. And the second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Globe Building. Snow falls.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (INTO PHONE, PRELAP)
dialogues.text: Larry, we're going to press in six hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike and Matt work the phones.

dialogues.speaker: MATT, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Donna Morrisey said she’d call us with a quote from Law hours ago.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: That's what I thought. Okay, When did you talk to her? Larry. Yeah. That’s good to know. Thanks, Pete. They hang up. Mike walks to the coffee machine.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Anything?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Conley said Donna Morrisey should have called, he just left Lake Street.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Rasky said the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: This is ridiculous. You'd think they want to get out ahead of this.  165 11/26/14 127.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: They'd be idiots not to. I’d love to see their faces when they read this. Both of them wait.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You know, Sunday’s the Feast of the Epiphany.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Seems appropriate. The phone rings. Mike grabs it.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Mike Rezendes. Hi Donna. Thanks for calling. I just had a few questions if you have a minute.... Mike listens. Matt waits.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? I just hung up with Larry Rasky... He listens, then grabs a pad and starts writing furiously INT. GLOBE, MARTY’S OFFICE - DAY 165 Marty sits reading copy. He crosses something out. Ben, Robby and Sacha sit opposite Marty.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Another adjective. Mike and Matt roll in.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Anything?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Law just turned us down.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I just got off the phone with Donna Morrisey. She said, quote: (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (off his pad) “We don’t even want to know what the questions are.” End quote.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: She really said that?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (slight smile) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (to Marty) That oughta do it.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (writing) “The Church had no interest in knowing what the Globe’s questions would be.” (hands it to Mike) Work it in somewhere before the jump. (to the team) Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Matt wants to put the letters online so readers can see it for themselves.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: We can run the URL at the bottom of the article. It’s pretty straightforward. No one really knows what that means.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: We also put the Spotlight tip line at the end of the story so people can call in. Goes directly to our office.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Matt and I will be in in the morning in case we get any calls.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I’m more concerned about the phones at reception. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: After we ran the Porter story, the message center was tied up for weeks. It was a real problem.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: And we had picketers. Lots of them.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I‘1l talk to Gilman about security and the phones. (to Robby) How’s it coming on the folo story? Robby looks to Sacha.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: We've nailed down multiple stories on seventy priests.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: All seventy?

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Yeah. And with the confirmation from Robby’s source, we're ready to go. We can have a draft next week.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Robby, that source of yours, is this someone we could revisit?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Might be tough.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: But he has no problem helping the church protect dozens of dirty priests. Guy’s a scumbag. Matt glances at Robby. Who’s looking at Ben.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: He’s a lawyer, he’s doing his job.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: He a shill for the Church.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: He knew and did nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: He coulda said something about this years ago. Maybe saved some lives.  11/26/14 130.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: What about us?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: What’s that supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: We had all the pieces. Why didn’t we get it sooner?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: We didn’t have all the pieces.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: We had Saviano, we had Barrett, we had Geoghan. We had the directories in the basement.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: You know what? We got it now.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Robby, this story needed Spotlight.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Spotlight’s been around since 1970.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: So what? We didn’t know the scope of this. No one did. This started with one goddamn priest, Robby. Robby looks at Sacha. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: MacLeish sent us a letter on 20 priests, years ago. Sacha found the clip.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Are you freaking kidding me? 20 priests?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Just after Porter. December of ‘93.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: We buried the story in Metro. No folo. Sacha found the clip.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: That was you. You were Metro.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah, that was me. I’d just taken over. I don’t remember it at all. But yeah. The room quiets. Gut punch. Ben shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Uh, can I say something? They turn to him.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sometimes it’s easy to forget that we spend most of our time stumbling around in the dark. Suddenly a light gets turned on, and there's fair share of blame to go around. (then) I can’t speak to what happened before I arrived but all of you have done some very good reporting here, reporting that I believe is going to have an immediate and considerable impact on our readers. (then) For me, this kind of story is why we do this. The team takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Having said that, Cardinal Law and the Catholic community are going to have a very strong response to this. So if you need to take a moment, you've earned it. But I will need you back here Monday morning focused and ready to do your job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The building is dark, save for the PRESS ROOM. Through th window, we see the presses. Running. INT. GLOBE, BEN’S OFFICE - NIGHT (FORMERLY 166A) 166

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, coat on, sits alone in his office. MARTY (0.C. Leaving?

dialogues.speaker: 166B
dialogues.text: 167 11/26/14 132. Ben looks up. Marty’s in the door. Ben stands.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Ben walks out into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and Marty walk across the quiet press room.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I just got a call from the Cardinal.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Really. Why?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: He wanted to tell me personally that he had decided not to comment. He said he wanted to, uh, extend me that courtesy.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Jesus, the balls on that guy. What’d you say?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I told him he was making a mistake. And that we were going to run the story.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Damn right we’re gonna run it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The papers run... INT. SACHA’S GRANDMOTHER’S HOUSE, DINING ROOM = NIGHT 167

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old, delicate hands move slowly over copy. Find Sacha’s Grandmother reading an early edition of the paper. Upset. Sacha, sitting nearby, watches her. But there’s no emotio no empathy. She’s blank, empty. Nothing left to feel... SACHA’S GRANDMOTHER Sacha, can I have a drink of water?

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Sure, Nana. Sacha gets up, walks into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bundles of papers fly down CIRCULAR CHUTES into the truck INSIDE THE TRUCKS, men grab the bundles, and stack them. INT. GARABEDIAN’S OFFICE, CONFERENCE ROOM = NIGHT 168

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVEAL Mitch standing behind his desk, at the window. He reads another early edition. Then folds it up and hands i back to Mike... who’s standing in front of the desk.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: Can I keep this?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Sure. I thought you should see it first.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: Thank you for bringing it by. Now I have some clients I have to attend to. Mitch goes back to work. Same old Mitch. Mike walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike walks back toward the elevator. He presses the butto waits, hears children laughing. He peers into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MOTHER sits with TWO YOUNG CHILDREN, ten and eight, pla innocently. The mother, distraught, fingers ROSARY BEADS. It’s reminiscent of our open.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN
dialogues.text: Both boys were abused. Jamaica Plain. Two weeks ago. In the HALLWAY, Garabedian stands behind Mike.

dialogues.speaker: GARABEDIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Keep doing your work, Mr. Rezendes. He goes in. Mike just stands there, GUTTED. Off Mike, his reflection playing on the window, CUT TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GREEN AND GOLD TRUCKS roll out from the Globe. We see headlights, a car waits for the trucks to pass. PUSH IN... and we see it’s Robby behind the wheel. CUT IN
INT. ROBBY’S CAR - SAME TIME 172B Robby sits in his car watching the trucks roll out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SPARKLING BOSTON SKYLINE. The City on the Hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A welcome mat. A copy of the Globe is slapped down. We se the HEADLINE: Church Allowed Abuse by Priest for Years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reveal Matt walking away from the door. We see it’s the treatment center near his house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're behind Sacha as she walks down the hall. She opens firehose box, grabs a key. Unlocks the door to Spotlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sacha enters, turns on the lights, takes off her coat. Ma enters.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Morning.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: How’d you sleep?

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Not very well. You?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I haven’t slept well for months. I’ve actually started writing.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Writing?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m working on a book. Gives me something else to focus on.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: That's great. What kind of book?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Horror.  175 177 11/26/14 135. Sacha reacts, the irony not lost on her. The phone RINGS. The tip line. They both stare. At last, Matt picks up.

dialogues.speaker: MATT, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Spotlight. Yeah. Yeah, of course. Can I get your name please? He grabs a pen. As he and Sacha trade a look, CUT TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The small visitor’s lot at the Globe entrance is empty, s for MIKE’S CAR. Idling. Robby’s car enters, pulls up next to Mike’s. Robby looks across at Mike. The two men connec Mike and Robby get out of their cars.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: You do know it’s Sunday, right?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I couldn't get a tee time. Robby smiles. Mike notes the SECURITY GUARDS at the entra

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No picketers.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Probably still at church. They walk in. Warriors returning home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike and Robby walk into the newsroom. It’s QUIET. Mike a Robby share a CONFUSED look as they reach the desk. LINDA the operator, and two others sit by the phones. BORED.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Hey Linda.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: It’s quiet, huh?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Yeah. Easiest overtime I ever made, phone hasn’t rung once. Marty sent two of mine down to Spotlight. Mike and Robby trade a look. Spotlight? They start moving  178 179 11/26/14 136.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (calls out after them) Great article guys.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY MIKE
dialogues.text: Thank you. Thanks. They hustle through the empty newsroom, heading downstair We hold on Marty, in his office. Working. As always.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robby and Mike charge from the stairwell. They quickly wa down the corridor with purpose. As they do, we hear... A MURMUR. Buzzing. And RINGING PHONES. Mike and Robby trade a look, pick up the pace. As they approach Spotligh the murmur GROWS. We hear more phones... and VOICES... Mike and Robby get to the door. We HOLD ON them for a sec as they stand in the doorway, looking into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chaos. Sacha and Matt and two INTERNS answering phones. Overwhelmed. An intern cups a phone, turns to Matt --

dialogues.speaker: INTERN
dialogues.text: I got another Shanley victim. SACHA I‘ll take it. (to Robby) The phones have been ringing all morning. Sacha takes the call. Nearby, Matt’s on the phone, markin up the board... it has tons of new names, phone numbers.

dialogues.speaker: MATTY, (INTO THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Uh huh, yeah. I know it’s This is Sacha Pfeiffer. Yes, tough to talk about. thank you for calling. Who am I speaking with? Mike and Robby stare. Matt spots them.

dialogues.speaker: MATT, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hold one minute please. (to Mike) Mike, could you grab that? Mike moves for his desk, grabs the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MATT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They're almost all victims, Robby.  11/26/14 137. This lands on Robby. A beat. Then he moves to his desk. Passing Mike, already picking up a phone...

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: This is Spotlight. Robby moves to his desk. He watches the team answering phones, working. A beat. Then he grabs a phone.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Spotlight. FADE TO BLACK. A CARD APPEARS. Over the course of 2002, the Spotlight team published close to 600 stories about the scandal. The card fades. ANOTHER CARD APPEARS. 249 priests and brothers were publicly accused of sexual abuse within the Boston Archdiocese. The number of survivors in Boston is estimated to be well over 1,000. The card fades. ANOTHER CARD APPEARS. In December 2002, Cardinal Law resigned from the Boston Archdiocese. He was re-assigned to the Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore in Rome, one of the highest ranking Roman Catholic churches in the world. The card fades. ANOTHER CARD APPEARS.
